content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												TL DR:Want to have steamlined,fun experience,without reading manuals or spending time pondering strategy?Go get X-Com Enemy Within,it is a great game.Want a game that expects you to think,learn,plan,and struggle?I'd reccomend Xenonauts to you then.This game...(was played only on Veteran difficulty,Community Edition.Dunno how much anything described below applies to un-modded game and lower difficulties)After beating the X-Com Enemy Within on Classic(read:"hard")difficulty with almost no effort in  the ' global strategy' part,I wanted to try something more like the original X-Com of which I heard (who didn't,really?) so much.But decided against Open X-Com and went for Xenonauts instead,as the latter reportedly was something like original XC,but with improvements in balance and UI departments....after 3 tries on hard difficulty,being absolutely trashed as late as 3rd in game month,trying several base-management strategies,around a dozen of squad setups,half as much attempts to manage my air fleet in such a way,so it won't be swarmed,outgunned,outrunned,outspaced by UFOs(unsuccesfully,so far),I dropped the game just to get a break and think of new ways to not get screwed after a few hours.Main part of the game is still a ground assaults on UFOsWhere newest X-Com had satisfiyng combat,it never once felt near so INTENSE(even on Iron Man) as it is in Xenonauts.I can't say for sure,why exactly playing Xenonauts I felt more engaged in the game.But when I had lost a squad member,or even a whole squad in X-Com Enemy Within my reaction was 'well,whatever' at most,after getting my A team slaughtered by Androns(terminator-stlye implacable SoBs) in the night ambush, I quitted Xenonauts for a freaking WEEK.Mind you,not RAGE quitted.I  just felt exhausted,because I had no idea how to win in that conditions,where I evidently screwed up somewhere strategically,so much that neither my air forces nor ground teams were up to the task.A week later,restart of the whole campaign and different approach got me through that road block,only I found a couple others...terror missions,enemy psychics,mind control...oh yeah.Yes,this game is brutal.But it is brutal in the most awesome and satisfying way possible,where you actually need to settle down and THINK about your decisions.Because if you did a wrong choice-chances are good that you won't get a disadvatage.Not being able to keep up with the enemy's 'arms race' will make it so that winning would be simply impossible.And no,it's not fake or unfair difficulty,because there's more than a few ways to do things right,as well as there is plenty ways to ♥♥♥♥ everything up.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												I just bought this game yesterday, so I don't know all the in's and out's of it, but I'm going to write my preliminary reactions.Xenonauts wins on the feeling alone.  I haven't played the X-Com games, new or old, but I have to say that something about the "look" of the new one turns me off, a bit.  While the AAA style of that game left a bad taste in my mouth, the old fashioned presentation of Xenonauts is quite refreshing.  The excellent paintings and graphics evoke a definite "X-files" atmosphere, and the soundtrack has an excellent atmospheric dread to it.  It is quite fun to send your squads through the map, clearing buildings and establishing perimiters, hunting down that lone bug-eyed freak who you just know is going to pop out and blast your guys with a burst of plasma fire.The amount of detail and depth in the simulation is quite good, especially for fans of strategy games which are more complex.  Woefully, many games these days have a "press x to win" mentality, but this game doesn't.  You have to carefully manage your funds and figure out your own strategies.  Should you build a second base early on, to keep the Russians convinced that your organization can do it's job?  Or do you spend your disposable income on tricking out your North American base so that you can more efficiently capture alien tech?  To sum it up, it's a little bit of SWAT 2 and a lot of X-files, all rolled up into a wonderful old-school experience.

												Xenonauts is a strategy game that closely follows the original X-Com:UFO Defense in which you order a team of people who should never hold a weapon to kill or capture aliens in order to turn back the alien invasion. It feels like they took xcom and refined the UI and controls to make it less tedious and 'mis-click' prone, you don't have to build alien containment chambers and there's less chance of you making your solider move unintentionally. content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												As some one who has never played the original xcom: ufo defence, I can thoroughly say this game doesnt just try to capitalise on nostalgia. It is a brilliant game in its own right. I would recommend it for any hardcore strategy fan. It can be very unforgiving and will punish sloppy commanders in both the overall strategic conflict and in the combat missions themselves. You need to stay vigilant as you are truly fighting a superior enemy. The atmosphere and aesthetic is very interesting and while the graphics wont blow you away, there are some really nice renders with some lore which create a good picture in your mind of what you are facing even if the little models of the aliens and men arent very detailed in combat. The music is also nice and eerie when you have to face the enemy or soars when your interceptors thunder towards alien craft to shoot them down. The combat itself is tactically very satifying. It has lots of depth and once you take the fight to alien bases and they do the same to you things really start to get interesting. I have many memories of individual missions and the stories that unfold in them. The heroic rookie that pulls of an unbelievably feat of bravery and kills the last few aliens even as his comrades' bodies grow cold around him. The time when I dropped my rocket launcher at the other side of the map coz my man got wounded and then had to hoof it all the way back because i had cornered an alien commander and i was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off and wanted to blow his♥♥♥♥♥to xeno hell. The bunch of ill prepared and under equipped soldiers who fended off an attack on my one and only base. There are plenty of moments like this. Buy it...and suffer! In a good way haha

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												Xenonauts-------------Summary: X-Com 1.5Multiplayer: NoCompletion: 30 hrsCards: YesCloud: NoCan't get enough old-school X-Com? Xenonauts strives to be the spiritual successor of the original game. It brings a little more of everything and streamlines features that should have been in X-Com in the first place, while simultaneously removing certain elements. Thankfully the story doesn't completely retread the original game, and opts to create its own alien backstory, which is fun to experience. The story takes place in the Cold War era, where everyone stops fighting and bands together due to the alien threat. Cue in the Xenonauts, a world-funded organization to counter the exterrestrials, study their technology, and adapt it for our own use. As the months go by, the aliens grow ever bolder, sending bigger and better ships, as though they are adapting to our own environment. Their numbers seemingly countless, they must be stopped, one way or another.Since the game is basically X-Com, I'll just outline some of the changes and what i think of them. The following are changes I thought were good:-All your loadouts are saved, and you can create your own custom loadouts and quickly equip soldiers to match that loadout with the press of a button.-Shields are a great item to have, and are much appreciated. Sadly you can only use 1-handed weapons with them.-Simultaneous movement. 'Nuff said.-Able to launch ships and soldiers while injured/low on fuel.-Civilians help you out! Suddenly the world doesn't feel as lonely as before.-UFO designs are varied and interesting.-I haven't seen aliens forever camp in one spot!-Walking consumes 3TU instead of 4TU, letting you scout about 33% further.-You are given all basic weapons for free in unlimited quantities.-Good tiles, though some art is a little off, like the portraits.-Enjoyable new story.-Air combat is very involved, though I suck at it. Also, they will run from your fleets, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.-Airstriking is great. I don't want to do every UFO mission.-Showing radar coverage is great. Makes me feel not-wasteful.-Stun rockets and grenades are great, and can be obtained early.-There's much less need of live aliens.-You are automatically refilled on supplies when the mission ends, thus you can fly multiple missions in a row in a single flight.-360 vision suit is awesome.-Easy to edit the game (though poorly documented).These are the changes that I feel could use some improvements:-Holy balls there's so many aliens! They always come in waves, multiple times a week, and the likelihood of one getting away is high.-Therefore there are a bazillion ground missions you could end up doing if you don't airstrike them.-Your aircraft are limited to 2 missiles. Considering the volume of UFOs that attack the world simultaneously, this problem is magnified.-All aircraft have considerable monthly fees. You don't even get a refund for decommissioning them.-Explosives destroy equipment upon death, which strongly discourages their use. Their blast radii are also way lower, further discouraging their use.-Aliens do not suffer from morale problems. I miss the feeling of knowing the aliens are panicking.-There is no means to train against psionics short of experiencing it first hand.-Aliens do not need to spot you before they can start blowing your mind.-No mind control or blaster launchers for your troops. Those were fun!-Burst fire got removed from most weapons. Those that do have it consume too many TUs.-The maximum accuracy on any shot is 95%, even at point blank range. You can and will miss on the 95%.-Weapons consume much more TU on average compared to X-Com, so you rarely get many shots on a full TU bar (not counting machine guns).-New weapons completely replace old ones. There are no TU or accuracy differences.-Most weapons are 2-handed now, removing many potential combinations that could have been fun.-Destructible terrain plays much less of a role. Stray shots rarely destroy stuff, and high TU-shots means creating your own entrance is rarely worthwhile.-Lack of instant movement. When you start to do dozens of missions, the time spent watching things move really adds up.-Maps are not procedurally generated. I saw multiple same maps in the same game.-Overhead map is gone.-You can't earn money through item production. Thus engineers are a constant drain on your funds, and they will never turn a profit.-There's very little stuff to buy and sell. Money is very tight in this game.-You cannot use alien artifacts. I miss being able to grab a dead alien's cannon and use it against his buddies.-You cannot fire in the air in a flying suit. So much for death from above.-As odd as this sounds, Xenonauts might be too long. It's very difficult to beat in one sitting, which is discourages replaying the game a bit. The fourth tier weapons might be overkill.-Sometimes crashes on Win 10.-The sarcastic scientist isn't very funny.As far as X-Com clones go, Xenonauts is probably the closest I've played that stays close to the original formula. It's a lot closer than the official XCOM: Enemy Unknown. However some of the changes they made oddly made the game less fun, such as the lack of mind control and blaster launchers. I don't deny these made the game much easier, but darn it, I just want to obliterate the battlefield and rain death from the skies. I like it a lot better than UFO: Extraterrestrials. I'm rather curious how they would write for a sequel to this game. By the end of the game you gain access to exceedingly powerful technology (infinite power??), and I can't imagine where they'd go from there. I give Xenonauts a 8.5/10. It's not without problems but is certainly a fine game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Let me start this review off by saying that this game is the spiritual successor to X-COM all of us fans of the original have been waiting for. Now, before all the Firaxis fans come out of the woodwork to make angry remarks, I have nothing against XCOM - from what I've heard it's a very good game in its own right; however from what I've seen (yes, I haven't yet had a chance to play it myself - yet - although the opinions I've heard/read and videos I've watched all seem to agree on this), the Firaxis remake changed the formula that made the original great into a more streamlined experience, that had been tailored to appeal to a larger audience - thus removing some of what made X-COM so enjoyable for some of us.However, Xenonauts has very much kept the formula the same. The basic gameplay mechanics are spot-on compared to what the original X-COM was like, except with some much needed touch-ups. First and foremost is the game resolution and interface - no longer will you need to suffer with an 800x600 resolution window and a clunky UI where the buttons don't reveal much ("What does this do? Oh I just placed some primed C4 at my soldier's feet"), and the interface taking up a third of the screen! Xenonauts has really improved these aspects and honestly, I really think that this alone makes Xenonauts worth considering, due to the sheer increase in playability that has resulted by actually having a nice, clean interface that didn't come straight out of the 1990s.Secondly, there are the combat improvements. They've really changed up the air combat in this game from what was in the original, and although I acknowledge that it's not to everyone's taste, it's certainly a lot closer to it than what X-COM's air combat was like, to be quite honest! All you really need to take into account are the manoeuvres (roll left/right and afterburner, primarily) for each plane and once you've gotten the hang of timing them and avoiding enemy fire, you'll be dropping those UFOs like flies in no time! (Although, don't mistake this for a lack of difficulty - some of the UFOs that get sent down to earth can be quite punishing!)As for the ground combat, not all that much is different from the original X-COM: soldiers are nothing more than fodder (don't grow attached and restart the game if you lose some; they're all expendable and you should always have a couple of Chinooks' worth rotating in and out of active duty, so you've always got some skilled backup soldiers in case a mission goes bad) who can all be killed by a single well-placed round by an alien if they're unlucky (it's always a "lucky shot" if the aliens happen to get you - ALWAYS ;) ), so using cover and smoke is very important. On a similar note, one of the things that Goldhawk have added to ground combat is a suppression system, where if your rounds miss the aliens (or vice versa) but either hit their cover or whizz by near them, they will become suppressed; meaning that they will drop to a crouch, will be unable to perform reaction fire in your turn and will have reduced TUs (Time Units) in their following turn.As for cons, I must say there aren't many. I'd say the only real cons are are there's not a HUGE variety of the randomly-assigned nationalities - although there's still quite a lot - and former units that help add some background to your soldiers, as well as the variety of generated maps being rather more limited than what was in the original X-COM. Although again, this isn't a great issue unless you replay the game a lot (but then again, who wouldn't?). However, due to the fact that modding this game has been made to be quite easy, there are community-made mods out there that remedy both of these cons.In summary, quite frankly I'm no longer able to recommend the original X-COM to people, simply because THIS exists, and that it's regular X-COM, but with some really nice improvements. If you've been hanging out for X-COM but want something a touch less dated, then definitely pick this up! I'm honestly very happy I Kickstarted this game a while back and I consider the extra money I sink into the game by buying gift copies for friends to be money well spent.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												The game I've been searching for ages. Since 2000 there has been so few of these really. Original X-com but updated. I've forgotten how much fun it is to individually equip tens of soldiers. Ground battles are as dangerous as they should be, air battles are innovative. Reminds be a bit of star wars rebellion space battles which was an excellent concept. But it's faster and more exciting.Realism is there and it's not been sacrificed in order to maintain game balance. Your tank is cheap and overpowering. If not very accurate. I've yet to discover many aspects of the game, I'm not googling stuff to gain advantage so I don't want to share my other guesses about the tactics. I might be wrong after all.There can be many additions for the game and from the start screen I understand that it is highly moddable. Which means a high replay value. I'm sure modders will add many fascinating stuff.In short, I highly recommend if you are a turn based strategy fan. If you are new to the gendre you might find it a bit old school but trust me, you will love it after you spend 15 mins in your first pass and will want to start again the game.It's not for casual gamer obviously. Even though it's not very hardcore, you still need some time to go through all the way and you need to be a patient wolf. It's not a fast pace game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												If you liked original X-COM, you will like this; it is almost exactly the same but with a much nicer UI.The cold-war setting adds an interesting flavour, and the overall feeling while playing is very tense. There are a few minor bugs I've noticed with the UI, but nothing showstopping. The only weak points I see are that the tactical locations are all very similar - they're using prebuilt tile maps and not randomly generating locations - it breaks the immersion a little bit when you  realize you've played the same map on a previous play. The dog-fighting mini game isn't very fun and you don't seem to gain anything by not using Auto Resolve. The Civilian AI could be a better too, as they seem to just run around in random patterns without any real objective or tactics. Keeping yourself in the black seems a little bit too difficult as well - but they provide full modding ability if you want to tweak any of the games parameters to tune the difficulty.Those points aside, I really love this game. I enjoy approaching it like a roleplaying game - naming all my soldiers and coming up with Cold-War-Esque code names for my bases, dropships, and vehicles. Highly reccomended for fans of deep strategy or tactical games.

Posted: July 13, 2014
												I played all the original x-com series and this is pretty good. however it has some balance problems and air combat can be quite repetative and slow. I just rage quit my latest game after turning up at a terror site to find at least 8 aliens stuffed into the corner of the map with me along with a bunch of blokes who were sitting ducks for the wierd things with fangs, so that number went up every turn. and as I didnt have laser weapons yet, each one would need multiple shots to take them down. even if they hit of course. the % chance of hitting something is wildly optimistic.so 4 turns in its obvious that this mission is toast, i've no chance. i could try and grind it out but i would loose all my men, leaving me turning to random soldier generator and its list of people with huge strength and accuracy but with so little bravery they drop their weapons and run off like a big girl if an alien so much as coughs on the same map, or incredibly brave people who have so little time units they have to run along at the back of the group trying to catch up like an asthmatic fat kit or with so little health they croak when they get hit by a so much as a glancing blow off of a nerf gun.or i could pack up the soldiers i have been training from that bunch of schlubs into an elite fighting unit and surrender and run off like the french army whenever they see so much of a menacing looking bratwurst appear on the horizon. And by doing that I'll loose a whole bunch of funding and possibly the region, so ending the whole game a bit earlier.i chose ragequit.again the laser weapon thing is annoying. you can pick them up off the aliens and use them, however when you end the mission they are automatically sold. WTF? Who in their right mind would automatically sell weaponry that a) you could use and b) was better than what you currently had? You can almost imagine the Python-esque conversation that would happen back in the barracks over that one...

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												I have never played the old 1990s X-Com this was based on, nor was I a really big supporter of the Indie game scene. My attention was directed towards Xenonauts, after a chance splurge had me acquire the new Firaxis X-Com, and while I found that game fun, I wanted something more challenging. Something mixing the depth of Jagged Alliance 2, with the concepts found in X-Com. And I found that in Xenonauts.After setting down my cash for this game after it's release, I have found myself hooked on it. The game has a great challenge to it. and I find the setting choice (Early 80s Cold War) to be very unique given most games of this type focus on the near future (201X) Earth. If X-Com: Enemy Unknown is a fun, console-ish romp, Xenonauts is the thinking man's version. You are facing a constantly mounting war against aliens, where you feel the underdog. You have to manage very limited finances, as well as maintain success in both ground and air engagements. You have to plan your base deployment, and do it very sparingly. You will quickly find yourself running out of money in this game if you aren't careful. You can also find your best men slaughtered by bad choices in ground tactics or your entire aerial squadron grounded for three days of repairs if you make a bad call while aliens ransack the world.This game is not brutal, but it doesn't pull it's punches. It reminds me of the old days of gaming, when PC graphics power had a "ceiling", so games had to focus on depth and gameplay. Xenonauts doesn't have the prettiest of graphics, but graphics is not it's selling point nor should the game be judged on such.My only complaint regarding the game, is that you can't use any successful profit-making skills in it, and while this has been addressed by Mods, my attitude towards Mods is skeptical, at best.I highly recommend Xenonauts, as it is a very amazing game given the limited resources the developer had. I'm now looking towards Indie Games, cause of what I saw Goldhawk Interactive do with it's Kickstarter campaign.I hope Xenonauts gets an expansion or some new additions, and that it's future is *NOT* left in the hands of User-Made Mods.

												I started off playing the revamped XCOM: Enemy Unknown on the Xbox 360 before converting to PC master race, and throughout that positive experience I would keep saying to myself "Wow this is easy, not a realistic view of an alien invasion" and then my mate said "want the next level, play this game" After several hours on my craptop (yes I have now upgraded) I spent a lot of my time completley getting my♥♥♥♥♥demolished on the Hard difficulty. If your looking for something challenging and in my opinion better than XCOM, welcome to the Xenonauts, an all round excellent Planet Defence Simulator that unfairly punishes you for the smalliest tactical errors, Enough said ;).

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												TL DR:Want to have steamlined,fun experience,without reading manuals or spending time pondering strategy?Go get X-Com Enemy Within,it is a great game.Want a game that expects you to think,learn,plan,and struggle?I'd reccomend Xenonauts to you then.This game...(was played only on Veteran difficulty,Community Edition.Dunno how much anything described below applies to un-modded game and lower difficulties)After beating the X-Com Enemy Within on Classic(read:"hard")difficulty with almost no effort in  the ' global strategy' part,I wanted to try something more like the original X-Com of which I heard (who didn't,really?) so much.But decided against Open X-Com and went for Xenonauts instead,as the latter reportedly was something like original XC,but with improvements in balance and UI departments....after 3 tries on hard difficulty,being absolutely trashed as late as 3rd in game month,trying several base-management strategies,around a dozen of squad setups,half as much attempts to manage my air fleet in such a way,so it won't be swarmed,outgunned,outrunned,outspaced by UFOs(unsuccesfully,so far),I dropped the game just to get a break and think of new ways to not get screwed after a few hours.Main part of the game is still a ground assaults on UFOsWhere newest X-Com had satisfiyng combat,it never once felt near so INTENSE(even on Iron Man) as it is in Xenonauts.I can't say for sure,why exactly playing Xenonauts I felt more engaged in the game.But when I had lost a squad member,or even a whole squad in X-Com Enemy Within my reaction was 'well,whatever' at most,after getting my A team slaughtered by Androns(terminator-stlye implacable SoBs) in the night ambush, I quitted Xenonauts for a freaking WEEK.Mind you,not RAGE quitted.I  just felt exhausted,because I had no idea how to win in that conditions,where I evidently screwed up somewhere strategically,so much that neither my air forces nor ground teams were up to the task.A week later,restart of the whole campaign and different approach got me through that road block,only I found a couple others...terror missions,enemy psychics,mind control...oh yeah.Yes,this game is brutal.But it is brutal in the most awesome and satisfying way possible,where you actually need to settle down and THINK about your decisions.Because if you did a wrong choice-chances are good that you won't get a disadvatage.Not being able to keep up with the enemy's 'arms race' will make it so that winning would be simply impossible.And no,it's not fake or unfair difficulty,because there's more than a few ways to do things right,as well as there is plenty ways to ♥♥♥♥ everything up.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												For decades people have been screaming "just remake the original XCOM with bugfixes and without the 16-bit limitations" and Mythos/Microprose have both resoundingly ignored this advice because uhh they're British and too busy driving on the wrong side of the road to listen to reason or something I guess. Anyway there was an open-source XCOM like ten years ago but it was pretty buggy and ugly and basically an uninspiring failure like most of the open-source Free As In I Don't Give A Sh­it games of the time were. But now these other people have made Xenonauts and it's exactly like the original XCOM but with bugfixes and without the weird 16-bit limitations so lol guess the original developers missed the boat on this one.There's also, of course, XCOM: Enemy Unknown, which is sorta like the original XCOM except dumbed down and with pretty bad/non-existent map variety. It's more streamlined and more instantly-playable than Xenonauts, but it's also dumbed down and the map variety is terrible. There's a place for both games. Get XCOM if you're a noob or Indie, Casual or just wanna shoot aliens or whatever; get this if you want the original XCOM, except with bugfixes and without the weird 16-bit limitations, or you're a bushy-bearded strategy game beardo.

Posted: April 25, 2015
												Where Enemy Unknown would take XCOM and modernize it in one way, Xenonauts would take the spirit of the classic and modernize it in another.If you wish for an XCOM much more in-tune with the spirit of the classic, scientist-hiring, time-units, chryssalid analogues and all that, Xenonauts is the game for you. It may not be XCOM by name, but it's XCOM by spirit.

Posted: February 11, 2015
												My introduction to X-COM was a mass effect clone called The Bureau, a very underrated game, but that's for another review. I also played another X-COM games like UFO, but that one was unplayable with my actual PC and Enemy Unknown a few weeks ago. So I'm not going to compare this game to UFO or EU and of coruse I will focus of why this game is great even if you never played a X-COM.This game has a great lore at even at 80 pages prologue novel, but it's not focused at all in the story, the entries in the xenopedia are fun to read but that doesn't count as plot. So this game focuses on the gameplay and it really shines in that aspect, every action cost Time Units (TU) and you can make any action in any order if you have enough TU, you can't shoot and alien move  to another position and if you have enough TU shoot another alien or reserver some TU for reaction fire in the aline turn.Xenonauts is one of the most addicting, well made and challenging TBT that I played, their graphics are pleasing for today's standards beside being 2D they are hand drawn style and the particles from the explosion, and shoots and others  are pretty well done.In conclusion Xenonauts is a great game for that's who love TBT and want something refreshing but just a pure TBT.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												This is truely the pennicle of the genere in my opinion. More polished and fun than the original X-com and more detailed and challenging than the "Enemy Unknown" remake, this game really scratches my itch for turn based tactics and global scale strategy.  It's not as pretty as a lot of other games, but that is well balanced by the addictive "one more turn!" gameplay. Of course, there are a few niggling details that are bothersome. Even at lower difficulties, this game can be punnishingly, frustratinly hard. When you're first starting out, it plays more as a rougelike with frequent restarts or save loads until you can get your initial base(s) established and have figured out a good order to unlock the tech tree. Additionally, the maps get reused more often than I would like, though there are workshop projects that remedy that complaint. Hell, even the difficulty ends up adding to the charm (and nostalgia) of this game. Seriously, though, if you're even remotely interested in this kind of game, you're doing yourself a diservice if you've not already aded Xenonauts to your cart.

Posted: July 19, 2015
												Xenonauts is an excellent spiritual continuation of a defining turn based franchise. The graphics, gameplay, and UI stay true where they were successful while parts that were lacking have been improved or redesigned. The game is very long, and in some instances will feel drawn out and repetitive, but on the whole it does not detract far enough to avoid playing.Know that this game is tough and will take careful thought, experimentation, and a bit of luck to win.

Posted: February 10, 2015
												If you ever played and enjoyed the original XCOM then Xenonauts is pretty essential while if you played and enjoyed the XCOM reboot 'Enemy Unknown' then Xenonauts is still worth looking into. In many ways this is the spiritual sequel to the original XCOM and while I can understand that it may be too 'hardcore' and intimidating for alot of people I still believe that anyone who enjoyed the XCOM reboot should still give it a shot. It might end up being too much for you to take in, or it might prove to be too difficult  but I'm pretty sure that you'll enjoy the process of discovering that because it scratches the same itch in so many ways. The base grounding of knowledge that you'll have from Enemy Unknown will also help you bed in gently as alot of the systems are very similar, it's just that in Xenonauts they're also that little bit more indepth. Steam Workshop support was recently added and already there have been mods uploaded which add even more variety and quality content to the game and I'm sure that in time that content can only grow. In short. Xenonauts is smashing. Give it a shot if you like this sort of thing. It was without doubt one of my games of the year 2014

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Super fun Alien defense game. I have always enjoyed super hard squad based turn based combat games and xenonauts is really good. If you liked X com Enemy Within/Unknown and want a more in depth and often more challenging experience play this!

Posted: January 6, 2015
												As a huge fan of X-Com/UFO: Enemy Unknown (and Terror From the Deep) I felt let down by the path of  the modern remake of "XCOM" with its smaller squad sizes, missions that took a fraction of the time, and the overall feel of its base management system.Well what have we here? "Xenonauts"? I have NOT been disappointed. Touted as the spiritual successor to the original X-Com games and it really does live up to the hype.PROs:- Base management: Way more in tune with the original, building hangars, labs, living quarters, workshops.- Research: Still figuring out the order in which I should be researching but loving it so far, trying to improve the classic stuff (weapons, armor, aircraft, etc).- That classic feel! Guess what? Your prize Lieutenant is going to get shot by an alien in the dark, your recruits (Privates) are going to panic, and that frustration of combat missions is really recaptured. You hate it, but you LOVE it!- Computer AI: Very very good. The aliens don't just walk around shooting you as they see you. They can be quite content to know you're outside their craft from having had their pal shot to bits, and hole up in there behind some cover... waiting for your Lieutenant to say... "open the door, Private!"- Mod community: Not looked into it, but like a lot of titles on Steam it seems to have a community for mods, and that can only be a good thing!- Music/Atmosphere: That sometimes menacing, sometimes spooky music from the old X-Com? It's not the same, but it has that same feeling.CONs:- They could do more to lessen the learning curve for new players. Things like outfitting your soldiers with grenades should be done as standard. I think I did my first 4-5 missions wondering why grenades weren't on Xenonauts because they'd be damn handy! Turns out they are, you just need to outfit your soldiers before the craft leaves the base.- Targeting. I know this will come across as a gripe, but when you run up behind an alien within touching distance, with a shotgun, get a 95% chance to hit and MISS... well, part of the charm? Or outright unrealistic? ;)OTHER THINGS:- Civilians are present on some of these missions, some of them are armed (most of them panic and crouch with their hands over their heads), but the armed ones  WILL fire at the aliens!- "Normal" difficulty. Damn hard! As it was in the original, and I'd recommend jumping in at this level for nostalgia's sake ;)Overall then... if you're looking to play an updated version of the old 90s X-Coms then I would HIGHLY recommend this. As always, check out some YouTube footage before purchasing, but I'm having a blast! Sadly, so are the aliens!

Posted: January 8, 2015
												Want a more upgraded XCOM? Here it is. It's literaly based off the XCOM series with the origenal in mind. I like it much better then the current XCOM, XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within. Xenonaughts incorperates indepth stratagy of bases, much more economics, and my favorite feature...fighter combat. Although it's not very complex, it's amazingly fun. I'd buy just the fighter combat as it's own game. Definatly worth the money, as it is half the price of Enemy Unknown and just as good.On a side note there have been some glitches, but that mostly involves my soldiers being able to see inside alien ships without suposedly being able to, and the occational sprite glitch. Nothing that breaks the game however.

The game is very long, and in some instances will feel drawn out and repetitive, but on the whole it does not detract far enough to avoid playing.Know that this game is tough and will take careful thought, experimentation, and a bit of luck to win.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												If you liked the original XCOM games, you're going to like this one. Isometric and turn based. Punishing ground combat that will drive you to save scumming. Steep-ish difficulty curve and minimal hand holding - apparently because the hands are busy holding a C4 with a timer set to 1 turn. What's not to like?

Posted: June 28, 2015
												This is truely the pennicle of the genere in my opinion. More polished and fun than the original X-com and more detailed and challenging than the "Enemy Unknown" remake, this game really scratches my itch for turn based tactics and global scale strategy.  It's not as pretty as a lot of other games, but that is well balanced by the addictive "one more turn!" gameplay. Of course, there are a few niggling details that are bothersome. Even at lower difficulties, this game can be punnishingly, frustratinly hard. When you're first starting out, it plays more as a rougelike with frequent restarts or save loads until you can get your initial base(s) established and have figured out a good order to unlock the tech tree. Additionally, the maps get reused more often than I would like, though there are workshop projects that remedy that complaint. Hell, even the difficulty ends up adding to the charm (and nostalgia) of this game. Seriously, though, if you're even remotely interested in this kind of game, you're doing yourself a diservice if you've not already aded Xenonauts to your cart.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												A good remake of the classic UFO: Enemy Unknown (or X-COM: UFO Defense for the 'muricans). Better than Firaxis' 2012 X-COM, though that game is good too. It's set in the cold war era, which is great, but not much is done with the setting. It's mainly in the art.Gameplay is pretty much the original UFO with some improvements, like bit more elaborate air combat and cover system. There is a lot of little things that bother me, but mods could fix the most of them, and there seems to be a healthy modding community. For example, the maps are generated semi-randomly like in UFO, but the maps generated are often boring, but there is mods that adds a lot of new submaps for the game to build it's maps from. The weapon tiers are a bit too obvious and gamey, this bothered me on the Firaxis' game too, but I can see how mods could fix that.Something not as fixable by mods is that the engine doesn't seem to handle z-axis so well. The sightlines are sometimes illogical when looking above and below. That's probably why the UFOs have teleporters instead of those lift tube things of the original game. The enviroment destruction seems to be on par with the original game, not as great as in X-COM: Apocalypse, but OK.It has some of the addicting quality of the original UFO. Endgame drags a bit, though. Overall very good and I got to try some of those mods.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Storytime - very mild game mechanics spoilers;It was my first base assault. It got called in the middle east, and I'd been putting the raid on hold for a geoscape week. The team was led by Lieutenant Jennifer Miller, a strong shieldwoman previously of the American Navy Seals. She was the one who I could count on to open doors and have the Reflexes to not take reaction fire, and "shock-jock" with a stun baton to take alien scum in alive.The firefights were long and daunting, fending off aliens in their own sprawl, and constantly keeping an eye on my rear-guard. Reapers and assault sebilians made me pay for every corridor in blood, to the point when it came to the alien base's command center being the last room, Lieutenant Miller was the only one remaining. A sebilian officer geared for war charged my team of three, killing the sniper who failed to hold down the kill zone corridor before the command room, and mauling a rifleman on its way.Lieutenant Miller retreated and bunkered down with just a laser pistol and a broken riot shield, ready for a last stand, but the sebilian officer withdrew back to the command room to hold the fort confidently. Lieutenant Miller fell back herself desperately, over the gore of firefights that happened a half hour ago. But among her dead allies, one had a RPG launcher still loaded, and some rockets on their belt. It was enough munitions to seek out the base's power core and destroy the base, but Lieutenant Miller wanted blood. Personally. She gathered up all the grenades she could find, and went back to the corridor, knocking on the command room's blast door with an RPG.They flooded through the smoke and fire of the blast, three sebilians, and opened fire as Miller was hunkering down and putting in another rocket. She took a graze, but responded with a stun grenade that culled the weaker ones unconscious, then filling the command room with two more rockets. To much relief, the mission became a success. The base was captured.On the lonely carrier back to home, it was shot down by a very, very angry squadron of alien fighters over the Atlantic. Yet fortune would have it that the local navy would find Lieutenant Miller barely alive out at sea, and ushered back to HQ to receive decoration and promotion to Captain for her legendary service.

Posted: March 15
												Xenonauts is basically a faithful remake of the original classic Xcom (not the recent new Xcom remake by Firaxis). Now if you played and loved the classic Xcom, you will definitely love Xenonauts as it plays almost identically like the classic (with some improvements). If you've only played (and loved) the Xcom remake, then be warned, Xenonauts plays very differently. I personally found the Xcom:EU remake annoying but loved Xenonauts, so i imagine those that loved Xcom:EU might find Xenonauts frustrating.If you've never played any Xcom before, then the game is probably only recommended for those who love a 'hardcore' turn-based squad-level strategy game. The game has a base-building resource management strategic layer, but the real meat of the game is in the tactical combat. You will be spending hours fighting battle after battle, poring over each squaddie's movement and facing, trying to flank enemies, agonizing over decisions to rush troops in the line of enemy fire, or taking risky shots with allies in the field of fire etc. If you don't enjoy tactical squad combat, then you won't enjoy this game. Take note, you WILL lose soldiers, don't get too frustrated over that.I completed the game on normal mode. Had to reload the game a few times due to some stupid tactical errors, but i didn't find anything to be too unfair/punishing. I don't play ironman on the first run-through cause i want to make sure i can reach the ending and i don't want to waste time constantly restarting. The game can get a bit repetitive  and 'grindy' in the later stages but taking my high leveled elite squad to the final battle and practically breezing through with almost my entire squad surviving and escaping was pretty satisfying.The only cons i have (other than slightly grindy later stages) would be the boring air combat system. After a few rounds of air combat, i resorted to just using auto resolve as i didn't find the air combat particularly engaging.Overall i enjoyed the game. I especially loved some of the improvements over the classic Xcom:- More organized squad equip/management with ability to customize your own soldier roles/class- A handy line of fire indicator so i know what objects are in the way- A nice suppression fire system (suppressed units cannot take reaction shots and start with only half TU's on their turn)- No more hunting the last alien hiding in some basement somewhere. Mission ends if you clear the UFO of all enemies for 5 turns.- if you are bored of sending your troops on ground missions, just airstrike UFO's from the air for some cash.

Posted: October 25, 2014
												Something about the screenshots of Xenonauts always put me off playing the game in the past, I couldn't put my finger on it; although I think the game itself looks great, the screenshots didn't do it justice. But as a big fan of the early X-com games as well as the 2012 reboot I was lured towards Xenonauts, it was one of those games that got under my skin, I kept looking at it on steam, on the fence as to whether it was worth the full asking price; I'd have to say after completing the campaign that it most definately is.Where as the 2012 Firaxis X-com reboot was more of a reimaging, Xenonauts is an up tp date version of the older X-com games, bringing back time units and a whole list of other unit statistics giving the game a certain retro charm.The main story arc of Xenonauts was brilliant, although it's another version of what has gone before, in my opinion it's a story which is more believable than those that have gone before it. The pseudoscience that backs it up is second to none and the tech tree that backs the game up brings some fantastic ideas with it, bulking up what we're used to in this type of game, again all of the research topics are given great entries, made to sound believable, as if all of the technology could potentially exist.The new additions over the original 90's X-com are great: - Realtime air to air combat between your fleets of interceptors and UFO's- A variety of weapons for ground combat, shotguns, assault rifles, LMG's etc- Suppression effects for human and alien units- The ablilty to see a soldiers stats before you hire them- Flashbang grenades for assaulting enemy units- Cover that offers units protection and can be effectively flankedIn addidtion to the above the alien units are all unique and all have unique combat tactics/ablilites which maintains a real "alien" feel to the first encounters you have with them, more than once I struggled to comprehend what I was faced with on the battlefield resulting in a last minuite change of my tried and tested tactics.All in all, a must for fans of the 90's X-com games; as well as those who enjoyed the Firaxis reboot and don't mind learning the new interface.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												As a fan of the original X-Com series, and someone who spent many nights shivering with tension on those critical night missions a long time ago, Xenonauts recaptures all of that - and more. It had a bumpy ride through development but honestly it has turned out a solid game, and I'm very happy to have supported it early on.One of the strengths of Xenonauts is the tactics that you can pour into playing the game, on the base management level, or the battle maps themselves. This is what people were crying out for and didn't really get in the otherwise decent XCOM game: the ability to fine-tune your planning and tactics, and go different routes. Tank and heavy weapons? Rapid response scout team? Traditional army style? Beserkers filled with explosives? Patient sniper team? You can make all of these work. Plotting your route through the maps and vying with the alotted time just feels right. And on the globe view - base placement, setup, research order, and all that. This all matters way more than XCOM. I'd say the AI - though not mindblowing - is just as good as the XCOM game if not better simply due to the more complex map design.Just play out your first night mission and listen to those noises. It's very dark out there and you're all alone and it's all going to go horribly wrong - maybe.One of the great strengths of this title over the originals, all the unofficial remakes, and the recent XCOM game, is that the maps needn't be repetitious. The system in place for juggling map assets does the hard work, and the editor is extremely powerful and will no doubt fill your hard drive with hundreds of variants (all of which, really, produce their own limitless variants). So if you take the time to download them, or map packs, or produce your own (it's fun!) you can cure one of the biggest nagging problems with the series' formula.Can't really recommend this strongly enough to strategy fans.

Posted: June 15, 2015
												This game is probably my favorite game in the last few years. Honestly, I almost like it better than XCOM: UFO Unknown. I've played through it once now. I DID play on Normal and without Ironman Mode and saved, like, every three seconds, but I still played it.But anyways, what's so good about it?-Feels similar to the old XCOM, which is good-Pretty deep base management-TONS of technology. More than either of the XCOMs. -An EXTREMELY awesome air combat system. Much better than either of the XCOMs. Instead of fighting one-on-one, you can go up to 3v3, and the way it works is almost perfect. Once you get the hang of it. Spend the time getting really good at it.-A pretty decent economy, you do well, you get more money. I do wish you could sell your advanced weaponry for more than what it is now. You'd think countries would want to get their hands on some shiny new guns.-Really good tactical combat. Lots of fun. Pretty darn hard if you aren't careful though. -Mods. You can mod the game. I haven't, but it's there.-Tons of overall content. There's not much I didn't like. Mostly just stuff with the difficulty. On normal. So, IT'S HARD. Get it if you want a challenge. IF you just want to blow stuff up like in XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within, this game might not be for you.As of the creation of this review, I have played one game through, which took me 40 hours to complete.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Awesome Turn Based Strategy(TBS) game.I have only clocked a few hours into this game, but what I have done has been very enjoyable.Not being big on games with a lot of text etc I have oddly found myself quite interested in the new entries that popup as you progress through the game, these detail new technologies you find, autopsy reports and other general info.The game puts you in charge of administering and controlling a organisation designed to intercept and stop and alien threat via advancing human technologies to and expanding your organisation deployment globally to defend against said alien threat.You do this by initially building a base, which gives you two interceptor jets, a helicopter transport and a crack team of individuals to neutralize any alien threats.Your base is equipped with a radar that covers a set range and when UFO contacts are detected you can launch your interceptors to shoot the target down.This is done in Real-Time and basically has you controlling the weapons and direction your plane(s) fly.Once you down the UFO you can deploy your transport of troops and land at the crash site to secure it in TBS combat FOR SCIENCE!I will not get too deep into it,The game is straight forward, easy to understand and follow the dev has done some great work in the lore and story and  it is simply enjoyable to play.Well worth the price if you are into TBS games and or the XCOM series.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Sooo, I am currently limited to a weak tablet as only means of computing power and decided to give this game a try, seeing it's requirements were rather humane and the screenshots looked neat. Handdrawn graphics, classic turnbased action. Seemed nice enough.What I got from that was absolutely amazing. This game managed to pull me in entirely and made me go through hours, making progress and playing to see what it might pull out next. The handdrawn nature made the absolute best out of this. Detailed depictions of the autopsies, backgrounds for the sections of your base that look like a masterpiece each and change over the time as you develop new technology. It really proves that great graphical experience has nothing to do with a powerful GPU.The narrative style of the game and lots of lore that come with it only increase the experience and keeps you going on, wanting to see the next artwork and the self loving speech of your chief scientist as he tells in his eccentric way of mixing imperial and metric systems what he developed this time.Gameplay wise there is nothing too revolutionary, the game relying on what had been proven good on the early XCOM games and making you wonder why so much was lost in Enemy Unknown. It's a good strategic experience that challenges your mind at times but doesnt frustrate you or make you desperate to a point that you toss away the game. I definitely recommend this to fans of Xcom and the genre in general, a good experience for casual players and more experienced alike and a pleasure to look at.

Posted: September 25, 2014
												I'll get the obvious out of the way; if you liked XCom Enemy Unknown, you will probably like this. If you liked XCom Enemy Unknown, but at times wondered: - Why can I only send one strike team at a time? Why only one base of operations? Why only one interceptor at a time?- Why do my troops seem to have seemingly unlimited sources of conventional ammunition? - Why are the aliens so reactive to my scouting that I'm rewarded for crawling forward at a snails pace to 'discover' groups one at a time, rather than actively scouting things out? - Why don't the aliens ever try a direct attack against XCom (if you have enemy within, why didn't they try for a conventional attack a second time?)then get Xenonauts; which does an amazing job of both bringing up the level of depth and realism that I've come to love from XCom (don't get me wrong, I think XCom is one of the best games out there and I love its character and offerings), and delivering something thats still unique and distinctive. If you're looking for a game that does an excellent job tracking what a campaign against a hostile alien invasion might be like; Xenonauts is amazing. Buy it; buy it now!

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Xenonauts has captured all the fun, excitement, and intrigue of the original X-COM games, and only intensified them in this amazing revival. With over 100 hours of play time logged on this gem, I can safely say that it is one of the most immersive and fun games I have played in a long time.      I have played Firaxis' X-COM and while I loved it, it still failed to quite capture the true spirit of the the original series. Not a problem with Xenonauts. Playing it feels like it was made by the exact same developers that made the original x-com, but with the approach and complexity that decades of gaming refinement have brought to the table.     I've heard some friends express a disenterest based on the graphics, but I can assure you that the elements of the game itself more then make up for this, and seeing how some 3D modeling can end up looking rather...cartoony or kind of silly (Planetary Annhiliation, Showrun Returns), I find it pretty refreshing.     I can't say enough about the content of this game. From the well written and detailed UFOpedia, that keeps a detailed description of every relevent item/creature you will come across and/or research, the rich histories of your team members; their prior combat experience, assignments, countries of origin, etc; to the HUGE tech tree to be plotted and explored.     The game takes place in 3 seperate environments...the "Geoscape", where you lay out your bases, set up manufacturing and research, hire and equip your soldiers/engineers/scientists, and watch for alien activity. Once an alien ship is spotted, you must dispatch interceptors to shoot down the enemy. Once your interceptor has engaged the ship, the second environment is entered     In the second phase, the "Tactical Air Battle" phase, you control up to several interceptors in a top down arial battle against the enemy ships. I have seen this tactical phase balance and transform as it was developed, and can say they have done a fantastic job with this and the balance as you research and develope more powerful crafts.      The 3rd and final phase is the "Tactical Ground Combat" phase, in which you control your customized team of soldiers (and various Heavy Weapon Platforms) in turn based combat against the alien invades after you have shot them down. You may also enter this phase without shooting down an alien ship if you get your lander to an already grounded UFO, a terrorist site in which the aliens are already grounded and engaged in terrorizing a major city you must defend, or an alien base they have established on Earth's surface.      There is a fantastic variety of terrain, maps, aliens, weapons, armor, etc throught the game, so it always seems fresh, even 40 to 50 hours in. even after my 120+ hours of gameplay (have played offline at times, who knows how many hours there) I still see new maps and have to come up with new strategies/approaches depending on situations.     All in all I would recommend Xenonauts to any gamer that won't be caught up on a lack of graphical complexity, and especially for anyone who likes management, strategy, simulation, or turn based games. At $25, this game is a great buy. I think the only thing keeping them from charging more is the lack of advanced graphics. The content is certainly up there with any Blockbuster game, in my opinion. Thank you to the fine developers at Goldhawk Ineractive for a wonderful product.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Did you used to play XCOM back in the day, and now crave a (slightly) more modern experience? Or maybe you played the new XCOM: Enemy Unknown, and found it a little too... gamey. Well, send in the Xenonauts!COMPARED TO XCOM:Xenonauts is a more user-friendly, streamlined version that replaces clunky UI for more strategic depth. And this game is DEEP. Spend you hard-earned cash on buffing up your wimpy troopers and giving them sweet, sweet gear or spend it like any rational government agency would and buy more bases and jets. Lots of jets. Upgrade those babies. Yeaaaaahhh... that's it. Jets are the future. I know those lasers look pretty, but jets make those governments happy... yeaaaahhhh...Also you'll be happy to find that, although challenging, you won't have your entire team mind-controlled on the third mission.COMPARED TO XCOM:EU or EW:So you have your flashy graphics and simplified UI. But do you have air combat? Do you have the possibility of managing multiple bases around the world? Maybe you just want one base to have xenonauts in it and the rest filled with jets. Maybe you can't aford anything because you are bad at finances. This game has all the strategic depth that XCOM: EU lacks. Pinch those pennies, ladies and gents.In Closing...For those looking for a more management-oriented, strategic experience, Xenonauts will be more satisfying than its flashier cousins. It has its problems, but the free Community Edition fixes the majority of them. I really hope XCOM:EU and its sequels consider adopting the strategic management elements from this game; it makes it a vastly satisfying experience.

content:

Early Access Review
								Hey kids, have you played x-com. The original one? [jontronmoment]wwwhuszat? yusaidno? Wellthat'sunbeliavable, i don't even see how you came to that conclusion[/jointronmoment]If you played xenonauts - you practically did. Basically it is a very faitful remake of x-com made by a huge fans, which resembles original almost on 80%. Everything is there - ability to damage terrain, free fire, science and assembly division, neat ambient music, etc.And it improves on so many levels which were under-taken in original x-com - like to example - aerial fighting manual mode is best one yet i've seen in fan-made x-com(1-2)'esque games. I mean - best one in series were in x-com 3, but i feel that lots of a-holes which did not actually played 3rd part gonna downvote me for that, but whatever. That's my review, i do whatever I want, god damn it.Anyway - the game is neat and polished -it crashed only 2 times in 13 hours, and i were able to quickly recover from autosaves, authors just need a little more kicking to make finishing touches and find all the bugs. But even at this point - this is very stable release candidate rather than beta.Almost everything is there, i believe teleporter and psionic sounds are the same, which they shouldn't be, also some plasma rifles have same sound. But besides that - core is there, feeling of progress is there too, game just as addicting to mea s the original, and i just spent 14 hours playing it non-stop, for the note - in recent xcom reboot i got bored after 3 (6 in ufo afterlight) and barely finished it. Something to cosider. I think main thing about this game is that it keeps throwing new stuff at you even after you think everything is done and beaten - on normal difficulty progression is rather slow, but rewarding at that - it doesn't feel rushed, nor does it feel too slow. Just hits the spot. In the conclusion - buy this game guys - it worth every penny and delivers+it has crazy potential for modding since EVERYTHING is in xml+it has map editor. And even if you played only reboot of xcom - but original x-com and this one and compare them back to back - they are pretty damn close and xenonauts most certainly can be called X-COM: UFO Defense 2.0.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Sooo, I am currently limited to a weak tablet as only means of computing power and decided to give this game a try, seeing it's requirements were rather humane and the screenshots looked neat. Handdrawn graphics, classic turnbased action. Seemed nice enough.What I got from that was absolutely amazing. This game managed to pull me in entirely and made me go through hours, making progress and playing to see what it might pull out next. The handdrawn nature made the absolute best out of this. Detailed depictions of the autopsies, backgrounds for the sections of your base that look like a masterpiece each and change over the time as you develop new technology. It really proves that great graphical experience has nothing to do with a powerful GPU.The narrative style of the game and lots of lore that come with it only increase the experience and keeps you going on, wanting to see the next artwork and the self loving speech of your chief scientist as he tells in his eccentric way of mixing imperial and metric systems what he developed this time.Gameplay wise there is nothing too revolutionary, the game relying on what had been proven good on the early XCOM games and making you wonder why so much was lost in Enemy Unknown. It's a good strategic experience that challenges your mind at times but doesnt frustrate you or make you desperate to a point that you toss away the game. I definitely recommend this to fans of Xcom and the genre in general, a good experience for casual players and more experienced alike and a pleasure to look at.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												To compare Xenonauts to XCom series would be the easiest, but also unfair way to deal with this enormous strategy. Quite certainly and without any shame, Xenonauts developers Goldhawk Interactive are speaking out the truth about their inspiration - Xenonauts is spiritual successor of acclaimed strategic game XCom: UFO Defense. Gameplay resolves in circles which comprises of three main elements: management of your bases and strategic command centers via Geoscape, your game screen; real-time air combat and final stage - turn based ground combat. Although we live in cruel time when hand drawn graphics are unfairly judged as unworthy by most of the (childish) players, get over retro, but charming hand-drawn sprites and you'll enter the world of comprehensive, multilayered strategy where you can manipulate every single aspect of your gaming experience. Numerous classes, weapons, tactics, strategies, upgrades and ideas have been brought upon the table and shrouded in mystery and atmosphere which perfectly collides panic of alien invasion and Cold war isolation.There are numerous selling points to Xenonauts, but one of the most important IS and SHOULD BE that it's an honorable, greatly improved over original and richer hommage to XCom which delivers in every single aspect. It's unbeliveable that an indie team can deliver a game that even surpasses the original on so many fields.If you're into aliens and hungry for some long-lasting strategic battles that will test your nerves, luck and decisions, go for it.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Below you can first find an in-depth 7 minute critique video and a written review below that. Thanks for watching and reading!


YouTube™ Video: Swash! ❧ Xenonauts Critique (Release Version Review) 

			Views: 4,531		

			An in-depth critique by SwashbucklingSir of the strategic tactical turn-based game Xenonauts, a remake of the classical X-Com series. Does it live up to the spiritual predecessors. Let's find out!		

STORY: Just as in the original X-Com games, extraterrestrial beings attack the earth and the poorly prepared humanity tries desperately to fend off the incoming aggression. Over time we learn to adapt and use the alien technology to our advantage, while at the same time stronger UFOs and aliens try to assault our planet.GRAPHICS: The polished graphics are quite nice and offer a throwback to the old generation, however offering a surprising amount of detail at the same time. Some levels are, by their nature (arctic and desert), rather plain and simple, however other areas are rather impressive.SOUND: The sound design is diffident. It creates a tense atmosphere where not encountering aliens is even worse than having them in sight. The minimal sound effects will make you sit on the edge of your seat as soon as something happens!GAMEPLAY: Both the ground combat as well as the geoscape offer very strategic gameplay and an immense variety due to an array of tactical possibilities! Balancing when to expand your base, which planes to utilise to intercept which UFOs, which equipment to bring for ground assault and when to know that retreat is the best option is key to Xenonauts. The air-to-air combat seems rather shallow though and I found myself using the auto-resolve function most of the time.PROBLEMS: The game does a really poor job of tutorializing itself and thus especially the UI, the cover system and the reaction shot system need a lot of getting used to. Once those initial hurdles have been overcome however, Xenonauts kept growing on me and the more I played, the more strategic options opened up due to the very flexible Turn Unit (TU) system.There are a few minor annoyances like the fact that the soldies customization is incredibly limited since you can only change their name but not face, origin, etc., or the fact that changing equipment is rather time consuming and laborious, or the fact that the UFO's doors close after each turn and thus you always have to put a soldier in harm's way, or the fact that doing an airstrike on a ground target is always worse than actually assaulting the crashsite with your soldiers, even though nothing is to be gained there, resulting in a grind, or the fact that the calculated walk distance sometimes is shorter than it could actually be if you would have optimized the path manually, or the fact that your soldiers cannot utilise their jetpacks to jump over stuff on the highest roof due to level restrictions, etc etc etc. Nontheless, I can forgive all these minor annoyances due to the incredible atmosphere that oozes from Xenonauts, especially when fighting at night in an uninhabited environment.There is one huge problem though, that still hinders me from playing Ironman mode, and that is the camera of Xenonauts. As it cannot be turned and as working with heights is incredibly clunky and frustrating, I feel that improvement on that front is required. Possibile solitions would be to include a rotate option for the camera or the possibility to switch off the walls similar to the Sims games. If no official solution is on the horizon, I hope and feel that the integrated mod support might lead to great solutions provided by the community in the future!COMPARISON WITH ENEMY UNKOWN: Xenonauts has a far greater entry barrier and thus addresses an audience looking for a more strategic experience compared to the latest X-Com game (Enemy Unkown). If you are new to tactical turn-based games, consider checking out X-Com Enemy Unkown with it's Add-On Enemy Within, preferably in a Steam Sale. Should you be looking for a hardcore experience reminiscent of the old X-Com games, consider picking up Xenonauts as it offers not only the tactical turn-based combat but additionally a strategic geoscape, which was simplified heavily in Enemy Unknown.CONCLUSION: Xenonauts is not perfect, however the tactical possibilities and the amazing atmosphere overcome the annoyances and problems. Thus Xenonauts gets a recommendation for every gamer with an interest in tactical-turn-based games.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Did you used to play XCOM back in the day, and now crave a (slightly) more modern experience? Or maybe you played the new XCOM: Enemy Unknown, and found it a little too... gamey. Well, send in the Xenonauts!COMPARED TO XCOM:Xenonauts is a more user-friendly, streamlined version that replaces clunky UI for more strategic depth. And this game is DEEP. Spend you hard-earned cash on buffing up your wimpy troopers and giving them sweet, sweet gear or spend it like any rational government agency would and buy more bases and jets. Lots of jets. Upgrade those babies. Yeaaaaahhh... that's it. Jets are the future. I know those lasers look pretty, but jets make those governments happy... yeaaaahhhh...Also you'll be happy to find that, although challenging, you won't have your entire team mind-controlled on the third mission.COMPARED TO XCOM:EU or EW:So you have your flashy graphics and simplified UI. But do you have air combat? Do you have the possibility of managing multiple bases around the world? Maybe you just want one base to have xenonauts in it and the rest filled with jets. Maybe you can't aford anything because you are bad at finances. This game has all the strategic depth that XCOM: EU lacks. Pinch those pennies, ladies and gents.In Closing...For those looking for a more management-oriented, strategic experience, Xenonauts will be more satisfying than its flashier cousins. It has its problems, but the free Community Edition fixes the majority of them. I really hope XCOM:EU and its sequels consider adopting the strategic management elements from this game; it makes it a vastly satisfying experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Xenonauts developed by Gamethunks, Goldhawk Interactive & released on 17 Jun 2014 for PC. According to Metacritic (http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/xenonauts) it has:    An Average user score of 8.0     #75 Most Discussed PC Game of 2014      #69 Most Shared PC Game of 2014  I'll dare say that Xenoaunts is a great remake of the original XCOM title. If you've played Firaxis's XCOM, you should give this title a try. Both titles differ in many aspect of the game however both are notable titles for the remake of XCOM. Xenoauts on the other hand could do with a little more love and attention for what it's worth.The Story:To keep it short, alien invasion on earth seems immanent and a multi-nationality milatary organization known as XCOM is task to defend our beloved earth from these invaders. Take command of this organization. Build bases across the world, research, manufacture and battle these invaders. One things for sure, soldiers will die. Period.User Interface,Controls, Visuals:The UI on a whole; on battle/soldier/weapon stats window were designed in blocks (nothing fancy), clean and organized unlike the original XCOM where there were tons/clusters of buttons on the  screen.The information are presented in a simple, clean & organized fashion. This also includes research result/aircraft/vehicle capabilities/alien autopsy. This is important because you may need to look them up after some time or after a break.To be real honest, controls are easy. It's quite standard for me really but for some who are new to turn base RTS, they may feel overwhelm on what's being shown on the screen. With the options and bars and what not & freak out far too soon. Or when they see the list of key bindings, the fall off from their chair. Lol. In actual scenario, all you need is the tab key and your mouse. That's it.Visuals:Xeno is a 2d, top-down looking game. It looks good for me. Nothing fancy  if compared to Fira's XCOM. The entire art style looks like hand drawn. Don't get me wrong, it is not a negative point. Everything in here has been designed/colored cleanly with details and a whole lot of effort has been put into the images as you progress with more technology getting unlocked. Unlike Firaxis's XCOM, where its design lean closer for sci-fi futuristic looking gears@soldiers. (those shiny & glowing things) Xeno takes place in cold-war era. Ballistic weapons, bazookas, grenades, tanks and jet fighters. You might feel unimpressed as you are in plain clothing with a standard machine gun/shot gun.  Due to word count limit, I'll just summarize that the human world art concept and the aliens art concept are totally different. Units, ships, weapons are all designed differently but with “realism” still the main point of design. Kudo's on the graphic department. Mechanics:I've said this and I will say this again, beautiful games without substance is no fun. What Xeno (may) lack in visuals, shine in it's mechanics & game play experience. Xeno resembles closer to the original XCOM with greater emphasis on micro managements. It takes a while to understand the weapon handling and on the TU points. Once you do, your gameplay are much more direct. In Xeno, there is no nonsense of that shot missing a 75% or 80% chance. Xeno shooting mechanic is more realistic and is largely affected by the  distance. The good news, there is base building and the aliens can invade your base. They can even build base across the world and you have to disable it. Similar to Fira's XCOM, once you lost majority of the world continent@support, you lose the game. Xeno has better air battles than Fira's XCOM. Air Battles are tricky when you don't have uber jets to fight for you. Some air battles require micro mgt to win. The ground battle is always tedious but rewarding. You need to understand the aliens capabilities and your weapon capabilities to have a decent chance against them. Failing to understand your weapon capabilities will only make you waste turns. Grenades are the highlight of xeno. They are an important asset to storming into room, provide cover and the best way to deal with aliens. Which is why Fira's XCOM later introduce enemy within with more grenade design.Game difficultyTo be honest, I feel xeno is generally harder than Fira's XCOM in the early days until Firaxis released XCOM Enemy within a major bump in game difficulty.I dont feel that the aliens are hard to beat or that this game is hard rather I feel that the game is annoying. Because the aliens capitalize on their advantage and with the constant nuisance from the praetor messing up my squad. But I guess, that’s challenge for you.There's day and night mission as well. Yes, Night missions are harder due to the vision disadvantage. To aid night missions, your entire squad is presented with unlimited amount of flares. It helps in a certain way but not effective enough because the aliens have higher stats then the humans and can shoot further. Oh and their weapon hurt more too. Many have mentioned this and I am going to say this too. Please re-tweak the reapers. They can see players out of the visibility range – they can move in and kill your squad with ease. It is rather an unfair design decision because the reaper only has to poke your unit and say goodbye to whatever Armour/weapon your unit has – or how utterly useless your squad reaction fire is. =(The final mission was really tricky, interesting and freaky suspense. As you try to make it out alive from the endless wave of repears. lol. On a whole, the game felt paced right. You are constantly battling against time for research/manufacture something to give you a slight advantage over the aliens. I use the term "slight" because no matter what tech-tree you research unlike in Fira's XCOM, xeno's aliens will always have the upper hand whether its in stats, numbers, weapons. I can share with you the moment I researched tank/super heavy suite/uber 1 blast kill weapon, I thought to myself: "this it man! this is the game changer!" but no matter what, if I am careless/I don't plan properly, the aliens will whop my sorry <bottom>. My SummaryXenoauts is a solid product. Thank you Gamethunks, Goldhawk Interactive for this product. While trying to stay true to the original XCOM title, many of the retro/feel/game mechanics have been adopted into this product. You did a great job with Xenoauts.Many might not have heard of xenoauts - unlike Firaxi's XCOM due to marketing approach maybe? But the gameplay experience is on par for both titles. It's not sci-fi and it tries to remain grounded on many of its design choices. Xeno does offer slightly more option for ground battle, where you are able to bring in a whole lot of soldiers (more than 6), the choice of soldier weapons and Tanks. Xeno gives you the option to train your soldier however you want and allows you to equip whatever weapon you so desire. The retro feel is there. Xeno's air battle@base planning will always keep on the edge as you try to cover a part of country/continent and prepare air crafts. All of the micro mgt aspect will allow players to feel more engaged unless you don't fancy that. I am a little disappointed on the ending. Upon completion and saving humanity from the alien invaders, players are presented with a screen of "hey congrats! you won!" After all that battle, terror missions, blowing up alien HQs, XX soldiers dead. My reward was 1 screen. Hmph. lol. I love the game, please don't repeat this in future titles. Please give players a much more rewarding "ending". Something which if they do share on youtube, people will go "wow, what a good game. I must get this" or "yeah you did good. congrats"So, on the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for Xenonauts is a solid 8/10.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												If you're a fan of the original X-COM: UFO Defense (or other Time-Unit based games, such as Jagged Alliance), then I highly recommend this game. I played X-COM: UFO Defense to death (I even beat it on the highest difficulty without saving the game) and I've played many other games in an attempt to capture that same gameplay feel, but without success. Until now.This is not merely a re-skin of the old-school X-COM, though it is very familiar. There is enough difference in game experience to keep the game fresh. I enjoyed reading all of the research reports and discovering all over again why the aliens are invading, and how to stop them.The game is challenging, but not overwhelming. I will very likely play it again.
