												Overall, Xenonauts is a very good and quite deep game. Definitely go for it if you can't wait for the next X-Com to come out.- Resource management is well done.- The geoscape "sim" mechanic is excellent.- I like air combat, but it can be skipped if it's not your thing.- Soldier progression works well and feels balanced.- Difficulty is well designed. challenging but feels fair.It has its flaws, however, Sound is scarce and poor... and graphics, regardless of being 2d (there are some beautiful looking 2D games out there), look dated (on purpose, perhaps?) and even bit unprofessional, which is a shame.

Posted: August 19, 2015
												THE GOOD:  This one is absolutely the spiritual successor to the original X-COM title from the mid-90s.  The avoid a bunch of the RPG gimmicks from the new X-COM games, and leave you with what is much more of a squad-based, turn-based strategy war game.  The atmosphere of the game is very well done, the various game mechanics and combat mechanics are very well balanced (e.g., finding the right balance in base-building between research/industry and defensive coverage of the map, finding the right balance in reserach between ground-based weapons and beefing up your interceptors, etc.).  And the nail-biting tension around losing your squad in battles was exactly the same!It  took me right back to the days of playing the original X-COM, and that is high praise indeed!There is also a small but very enthusiastic modding community for this game, so check out the Steam Workshop.THE BAD:  I found it a little bit of a grind later on in the game.  Too many repetitive base assaults, too many repetitive missions to "kill and autopsy" or "capture and interrogate" one more unfamiliar alien, and the formula of "capture this type of alien" to advance the main story line got a bit stale after a while.  That was after 60+ hours of delightful game play, so take that with a grain of salt.

Posted: August 5, 2015
												About as close as you will get to the original XCOM experience.  Although the graphics are lackluster, this game has all of the elements that made XCOM such a memorable game.  It also includes common sense improvements and minor embellishments that add to the theme without deviating too much.Just like the original, you will find yourself gripping the arms of your chair as you find out whether that last shot you fired will kill the alien that is about to throw a grenade that will incapacitate half of your team. You will sacrifice squad members to capture alien leaders for interrogation.  You will make the hard decision to let a city or two be terrorized to better utilize your resources elsewhere.The bottom line is that this is simply a much better game than the much praised official XCOM remake.  Fires, night missions, base invasions, terrain destruction, and most importantly:  a sense of dread as you barely hold off waves of alien infestation.  Highly recommended.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												This is one of the best turn based strategy games I have ever played. It is very well made; I have seen no glitchs or bugs, and the controls make miss-clicks a rare occurence. The difficulty scale is great as well. At the lower levels, it is more forgiving for new players yet still really fun. At the higher difficulties, it requires a high level of both stategic and tactical knowledge to survive, providing a very satisfiying challenge that I have not seen since Civ V.The only problems I have with the game is that it does not tell how long some things may take to do, like researching tech and hiring new personel. This is a minor issue however, because after several playthroughs you have a general idea of how long these things may take to do.Overall, Xenonauts is a great strategy game (9 of 10) and is well worth playing.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												I am not going to review the mechanics of this game. There are far better game reviews out there for this. Instead this couple of paragraphs are mostly for those of you that are on the fence about purchasing this game. I purchased this game right before it came out of beta but I would have happly bought it even at its full price. The original X-Com: UFO Defense (1994 MicroProse) was a truly remarkable game and but for the graphics stands up well to games released today. Xenonauts recreates the original game (with a few extra suprises) very well. The developers have updated the graphics and improved the AI. The game is challanging even on the average setting. I have yet to try the higher settings. If you have never played the original X-Com, this game is a must. If you have played X-Com, you owe it to yourself to get this game. It will bring back memories of sitting in front of your computer for hours on end trying to destroy the alien base and save the world.So, if you are on the fence, don't be. Click the buy button. If you enjoy turn based squad action, you are going to love this game.

												Amazing x-com remake. If your a big fan of the original x-com you'll love this game. Don't expect anything new, its just a clone, but its extremely well done. Posted: June 24, 2014
												I  only have a few hours of gameplay under my belt at this point, but at this moment I am willing to call this game incredible!  I have played and liked the Xcom remake, Silent Storm, and some of the UFO series; I consider this game to be a peer of that group, and it has qualities that make it extraordinary in it's own right.  I was worried about the graphics, if it would present barriers to imersion.  They didn't.I was worried it would be simple, a series of milk-runs.  It is not.  It presented a deep tatical chalange that I am still not equal to.  I remember the first mission where no one died.  That left me with a good feeling and a real sense of achivment.Note: I sometimes need to open Task Manager after launching the game, and end the application, if the launcher does open. Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is a quality revitalization of the original X-COM.  It not only met the high standards set by the 90s classic but also exceeded the benchmark in many ways.  - This is a global war fought by many nations that join in the fight.  Militaries around the world as well as farmers with shotguns will aid the multi-national force in its fight against the alien invasion.  Occassionally they bring down alien crafts (at terrible losses),   Allied units are represented as cops on the street, farmers blasting aliens on the other side of the farm as your troops hunt aliens around haystacks, or national militaries desperately defending the city during terror missions  - Interception missions are extremely fun - take personal control of your interceptors to bait and flank enemy crafts once your squadron catches up to an enemy flight (it could be a battleshield escorted by two fighters, or just a lone scout) - this minigame is many times more fun than X-COM's interception mission.  - Your soldiers earn medals for performing extraordinary tasks - the medals in turn boost their stats- Many weapons to choose from - riot shields (wield one with a pistol), shotguns, rifles, sniper rifles, RPGs, HMGs, researched alien technologies, even a TANK that will eventually look like a real tank (upon further research).  Who doesn't want to use a tank to blow away aliens?  In X-COM games, the tank is always a tiny robo-craft that look gimpy... here we have a real tank!  - Addressed many short-comings in the original X-COM game.  You can now fly the troop transport to multiple crash sites, direct interceptors to target one group of enemy after another (assuming enough ammo and fuel left).  - It is a challenging but highly rewarding game.  It is fair (none of that enemy "spawning" behavior in X-COM Enemy Unknown), but it is tough.  I would rather have a tough game that is fair than an easy game with funky game logics. I am an avid X-COM player: 5 playthroughs in the original X-COM, 1 playthrough of TFTD (ok that was torture), 1 playthrough for Apocalypse, 1 playthrough in X-COM EU.  I am proud to say that Xenonaut has won me over as the quality spiritual successor that I have always been looking for.

												A great recreation of the original X-Com, with some much appreciated improvements to air combat and simplification of the base management UI and so forth. Posted: July 8, 2014
												This is not a recreation of the original xcom. This is an improvement. Everything is a complete improvement. Instead of sending out lone interceptors to fight off lone ufos you are able to send multiple fighters after a ufo and its escorts. It also gives concrete reasons for the invasion starting off so slowly. The ufo's are not suitable for atmospheric flight and must be modified and the smaller the ufo the faster and easier the modification. It also expanded on the variety of weapons you can equip your soldiers and the utility of other weapons. For example stun gas rockets and the addition of suppressive fire giving lmgs a more significant purpose than being extra powerful rifles.

Posted: March 11, 2015
												This game is a good remake of XCOM: Enemy Unknown. It adds some improvements in the tactical combat screen and the Geoscape, however some things are too streamlined for my liking. An example would be not having to purchase ammo or the starting weaponry. These issues were minor for me and overall the game is very enjoyable althogh a tad expensive  at 28$ CAD for what is essentially a 2d remke, albeit a very good one. This game has excellent mod support and a great community. I personally enjoy a mod that randomizes the tactical battle scape for more interesting combat. I also use a mod that redoes the tundra and base terrain and have only ran into one bug with these mods that has not repeated. There are many other Steam Workshop mods available so there is sure to be something to suite your tastes.Congratulations to GoldHawk Interactive for stepping up and giving people what they wanted by rebuilding a classic game. I hope there will be a sequel that is similar to XCOM Apocalypse =DEdit: I am editing this review after discovering another level of tech in this game.  There are 3 tech levels plus the starting tech level for a total of 4 tech tiers. This is alot of tech to research and is a wonderful part of the game. I made a mistake when I said this game was  tad expensive. It is well priced for the amount of content available as well as the amount of support the developer/publisher give the game. Once again well done GoldHawk Interactive, you have made an excellent fan and I wish you all at GoldHawk the very best.! =D

								At the time of this review, the game was still in development and thus there were some glitches, bugs and balance issues.With that in mind, I still recommend this game as a somewhat successful x-com copy. Graphics arent the best, but I have to admit that old school graphics scare me more than fully detailed 3d and shiny aliens in newer games from bigger studios. the pace is quite slow and you have to ponder every move, slowly get your team into position for every corner (a thing about tactical turn based games) Difficulty wise, Xenonauts is a bit tough on beginners, however if you are reading this, that means you are after some depth and challenge in a game, anyway. For x-com veterans it should be a walk in the park (while getting killed many times by an unseen alien and reloading every now and then)Although targeted to a limited market, this game can only get better with time as developers work on it.

Posted: April 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								What can I say about Xenonauts? Well, if you are an oldie such as I. Then you will come to appreciate old classics, like Ufo Alien defence (The old X-com), Jagged Alliance 2 and Panzer General. With the exception of Panzer General, the other two are very similar games. With their core underlying mechanics being grounded in managing a team of soldiers in accomplishing some sort off objective. How is that relevant? Well, for starters. You need to understand what this game is trying to accomplish. And that is replicating an old classic and making it more pleasing to the eye. The 'pleasing to the eye' has already been accomplished by the remake Firaxis has made. So again the question is: What does this game bring? Well it successfully manages to incorporate the core aspects that made the original Xcom so great into a neat little package that is pleasing to the eye and keeps the features rich. 'Feature Rich', that is the key here. Everyone including me loves the new remake of X-com very much, but again, if you are like me. Then you will yearn for the classics. In that case, what better then to play a pseudo remake?

												This game is a must have for any fan of tactical/strategy based games.If you loved X-Com you'll love this, interface is clear and simple, no clutter, easy to find what you need.the AI offers a genuine challenge, it's delightfully unforgiving so save scum often, there is lots of lore to enjoy if that's your thing and lots of researching to be done if you want to stand a chance at winning.For sure a 10/10, one for the collection of any Commander.

Posted: July 29, 2015
												This started out hard, but fun. And then psionics happened to it. For a supposedly tactical game, half your success on missions comes down to "not failing your save against psionic enemies with unlimited range and no line of sight required". You don't get psionics to throw back at them, you don't get any counters to it, and you have no idea where the attacks are coming from. Usually it's some enemy on the far end of the map, so you can't even try and rush them to remove the threat.It's not a challenge, it's just random rolls that occasionally mean half your team freezes and you waste a round. This game would have been better off without it, or limiting psionics to line of sight so you can do crazy OP tactics like "scouting" and "planning". Get XCom-Enemy Within, it uses actual game difficulty rather than arbitrarily zapping you.

												XCOM:UFO Defense was released the year I graduated. Let me clarify that I do not remember the release date because it is the same as my graduation. I remember my graduation date because of the release date. I first saw this played on a 486DX and then had to hack and upgrade my Tandy 1000EX to be able to run it. I spent $700 in 1993 money to upgrade my RAM to a whopping 768kb. In the end I upgraded machines to play this, Mechwarrior and AOE.I have also played numerous attempts at sequels, upgrades and fan made remakes. There is NOTHING that come even close to this one. Posted: July 14, 2014
												EDIT - (some 20 hours of gameplay later...)Having tripled my playing time and gotten deeper into the game I have gone from 'pleased' to 'impressed'. The curve at the lower levels is pretty good. You develop your newer guns, finally build and issue some, have fun for a mission or three and then suddenly 'WHAM'! New alien to bring your ego back crashing down.The air war ramps up quickly to the extent that while you start to feel you can handle everything being thrown at you on the ground, even at EASY you get the impression you just do not have enough intercepters and you never feel completely confident about handling all of the latest swarm.Having played more I have realised there are a lot more maps then I first assumed. Still not so many that you don't start recognising previous locations from time to time, but definately enough that even after 30 hours you are fighting on areas you haven't experienced before.Lot of fun, has that 'just play for a bit longer until...' attraction that easily chews up the playing hours but again, if you are not an existing XCOM fan then this game may seem a little old school to you.(end edit)(based on v1.07 and 11 hours play on Normal)Tentative THUMBS UP.Thing to remember is this game is Xenonauts, and NOT X-COM classic with better graphics. If it was sold as X-COM Classic -HD version or something similar.What that means is that, surprise! there are differences. Bases are now only one level, the world map is 2D rather then the funky globe. Some of the starting weapons and equipment from Classic either require research or are simply not within the game.Why?Because it is a different game and let's be honest, if you think classic X-COM was better, then maybe you should go play that instead (hint, I still do - or would if it wasn't so punishingly hard!! :D )The game is a bit of a mixed bag. Some of the interfaces are very simple, some (research screen I am looking at you) are downright ugly. Combat seems easier (in that it is possible to complete the early ground missions without having half your squad KIA) and the way reports of 'strange' activities pop up on the global map is interesting. You wont spot UFOs outside your radar coverage, but by looking at the reports of corp circles and abductions you can sometimes have a good idea where to send out a patrol.Ground maps are no longer randomly generated as they were in classic. On the plus side they now look a lot better, on the down side there is no longer the tenseness of simply exploring the map to work out where the drokk you actually are. Hopefully the game will add new maps with upgrades as once you have explored a map for the first time, remembering the danger spots with weird lines of sight is reasonably easy.Slightly disappointing is that crashed UFOs are no longer massively damaged when you arrive. Player's of classic will remember turning up on a crash site to find half a wall section and some un-lootable piles of smoking scrap and can breach the craft from the gapping holes your air to air missiles made in the hull. This means that every combat seems to back down to going in through the front door. Oh well.Some of the micromanangement has been removed. Everything you can't use yourself is automatically sold, so you no longer have store rooms full of stuff you are loath to get rid of.Also slightly disappointing is the study of the corpses you bring back, which are now done automatically. Gone is the choice between removing your limited science teams from the new lazer rifles you want to develop in order to study the latest hunting trophy.So, I think this is a good game. Maybe not 'great' and maybe not the sort of thing you would be interested in as an XCOM newbie trying to work out what the fuss is about.

Posted: April 17, 2015
												This is what I think X-COM Enemy Unknown should've been like: a balanced turn-based-strategy game that rewards your intelligence and punishes your mistakes, and ONLY your mistakes. It's challenging without finding the need to cheat.The gameplay is almost exactly like Enemy Unknown. But the few differences that are there make the game a lot more fun and a lot less frustrating. For starters, enemies no longer get a free move when you spot them, evening out the playing field. Their advantage instead comes from other abilities they have, such as regenerating damage, teleporting, flight, and psychic attacks (the latter of which has cost me more than one mission). These make them hard, but unlike X-COM where I found the game boiled down to "shoot them until they died", this game instead forces me to prioritize targets based on potential threat from things other than how big the aliens are and how big are the guns they're carrying. Each enemy unit merits a different approach, as it should.Your soldiers don't get specialized abilities like they do in Enemy Unknown, but they're no longer arbitrarily placed into categories by whatever confusing algorithm turned all of my soldiers in to snipers and nothing else. Their effectiveness in combat boils down to what equipment you arm them with vs. how well suited they are for that type of combat according to their stats.The air-to-air combat is FAR superior here than Enemy Unknown. There's an actual strategy element to it not that gives you more direct control of combat, allowing you to snatch victory from a 96% chance of defeat with some creative flight control and use of weapons.The world map is also much improved. Rather than build satellites to watch over whole continents, you instead build bases at points where you can cover the most land with your limited radar. And aliens can always attack your bases, setting you back and possibly costing you the game if they're not properly defended. The limited space you have to build aircraft will more often than not force you to guess which ships pose more of a threat than others, until later in the game when you can build an intel array to spell it out for you.Eventually, your equipment will outmatch that of the aliens', but said equipment is costly and takes far more time than is practical to build. What makes this and pretty much every other step forward in Xenonauts work, though, is that your triumphs only come after numerous successful missions and God knows how many soldiers lost to the enemy.And, lastly, f**k those f**king Reapers.

Posted: January 1, 2016
												Essentially, this is an alternate universe version of XCOM harkening back to the classic titles and done fully in 2D. And how good is that 2d? I love it. Huge respect to the team at Goldhawk for going all in and not taking the easy way out with halfassed 2.5D/3D. In my opinion being 2D really adds to the classic vibe.Compared to Firaxis' XCOM this definitely feels like an older game. It's more complex, much more challenging outside of ground combat. In XCOM you basically only need to worry about ground combat. In Xenonauts you have to maintain multiple bases, multiple teams of soldiers, cast a wide enough net of radars to protect as much of the earth as you can, and manage your air force against the waves of UFOs that even threaten to attack your bases if left unharassed (and if they do they aliens will come in and try to break all your stuff). And all that before you even get to the ground combat. Both games feature similar research that provides gear that you need to stay on even keel with the aliens who get progressively more powerful, and the research also drives the story along in both. Though Xenonauts doesn't really have a story in the way the XCOM does, in Xenonauts the narrative is your own, there's no cutscenes or dialogue or anything.The ground combat is also much more complex in Xenonauts, choosing to use "time units" rather than XCOM's two actions per soldier method. Most weapons have several firing modes available taking different amounts of time units, switching weapons (or grenades) takes time units, etc. Also cover much always always always be used, a soldier left in the middle of the street is liable to get shot by an alien you can't see.One major gripe I have with Xenonauts' ground combat is that downed UFOs only have one way in, the front door. This means you have to funnel your troops in through the front door where a bunch of well armed aliens are sitting waiting violate you. The combat requires well thought out tactics in order to survive, and yet you're forced to charge headlong at angry aliens, ehhhh.On the whole, Xenonauts is a more calculating, complex, slower paced game. XCOM is snappier and more gamey. They both offer a different approach to the alien invasion. Xenonauts is a more niche take to XCOM's mainstream accessibility. Personally, while I recommend this game to XCOM fans or fans of tactical strategy type games, I don't know how much more I can withstand, it's very stressful. It's always heartbreaking to lose your elite guys in XCOM, but in Xenonauts I just keep losing everything, game's hard man!

Posted: August 5, 2014
												I've played thousands of hours of old X-COM (UFO Defense, Terror From The Deep, Apocalypse), and over 500 hours of Enemy Unknown/Within.  I'm enjoying Xenonauts tremendously.  Details follow, but if you're a fan of the old-school X-COM games, I'm already telling you that you should check this game out.Xenonauts describes itself as a "spiritual successor" to X-COM.  It's important to note that they were very probably not talking about Enemy Unknown/Within; the differences in polish will disappoint you if you're expecting that level of visual quality.  However, as a successor to -old- X-COM (UFO Defense, Terror From The Deep, Apocalypse) it succeeds pretty brilliantly.The look and feel of the Geoscape is very UFOD/TFTD (only much prettier), while the tactical aesthetics are much more like Apocalypse turn-based mode.  Bases have radar ranges determined by the number and quality of detection facilities present, but the range limits are far more visible than in previous games.  This makes it far easier to understand the coverage consequences of base placement. Ship Combat:  X-COM ship fights (even in EU/EW) are like sumo wrestling.  The ships' locations on the field are completely abstracted away, and there are hit percentages simulating mobility, so you see two craft holding relatively still and slugging at each other.  Misses look more like bad aiming than evasive action.In Xenonauts, the ship combat display is a 2D grid wherein momentum and turning radius count.  Weapons have ranges and firing arcs, ammo and fuel count, afterburners are a thing (but see: fuel counts) and missiles have their own maneuverability values.  Defensive maneuvers exist for evasive actions, and a dogfight isn't always 1:1 -- in fact, encounters can get up to 3 vs. 3 in some cases; as UFO's begin to appear with escorts, and fighter squadrons roam in packs daring your interceptors to come out and play, you respond by sending attack groups instead of lone planes.  There are light and heavy interceptor classes, with maneuverability, range and armament consequences.  You can't form an attack group out of craft from more than one base, unfortunately.  I'd have loved to see a rendezvous point system wherein disparate fleets could join up, but ship combat is a fun, complex mini-game in and of itself and a strategy guide could be (and probably has been) written just for that facet of gameplay.  NOTE:  There are -way- more UFO's in the early part of the game than in any iteration of X-COM.  This becomes important during...Ship Combat Aftermath:You can send troops to fight at a crash site, but that's not always an option.  You probably don't have enough strike teams to cover every site where you've shot something down, especially early on when a single Condor is still a match for anything the aliens field.  Rather than letting the sites rot and taking a PR penalty with the nation where they crashed, Xenonauts provides the option to call an airstrike and saturate that area, then send a non-combatant cleanup team to salvage what it can.  This results in a static amount of cash based on the class of crashed craft, and a few recoverable items, but no soldier experience or personnel equipment captures.Soldier Management:  Enemy Unknown/Within introduced the concept of soldier classes; a Rookie, upon promotion to Squaddie, was assigned one of four classes.  That class distinction determined what stats increased when the soldier was promoted, what weapons the soldier was allowed to carry, and what special abilities became available to that soldier as rank increased.  It's a novel concept, but there are downsides.  Class assignment is for life, for one thing, and there's little room for creative misuse of inventory -- you can't load down an Assault trooper with grenades, for instance.  Nonlethal weapons were considered Items rather than weapons in EU/EW, as well, which meant that you had to choose between that and grenades, or extra armor, or whatever else.  It added importance to the range of choices, but only by limiting them. Xenonauts doesn't have classes, but it does allow you to assign a soldier a role.  The main differences are that any role can technically carry any equipment; there are customizable default equipment templates for each role; you can change a soldier's role in the barracks anytime the soldier is on base; and you can create new roles.  Weapon disparity is a little wider, and there is in fact a "laser shotgun" and other mechanics-only nonsense, but in general the strategic and tactical choices you can make in Xenonauts is far wider and more granular than in its ancestors.Tactical Combat:Oh, man.  Where to start.  Quick list of things that don't require explanation:- Stun rockets are a thing.  You get them as soon as you get stun grenades.- You don't have to wait half the game to get stun grenades.- Nonlethal melee weapons exist, and they're weapons -- not some other item class.- All soldiers carry an infinite number of flares!  (But vehicles don't.)- Vision arcs are back.  An unarmored human has a 90-degree effective vision arc.  (Heavy armor can reduce this.)- Cover is not a light switch like in EU/EW, but rather a stack of calculated obstruction percentages like in older X-COM titles.  Stuff that might require some more description:- Range matters a lot.  Different weapons are optimized either for long-range armor-piercing fire, or massive trauma at point-blank range.  You have to make sure you send the right soldier for the right tactical situation, all the time; the aliens are as merciless as they ever were in TFTD, and a soldier caught at a disadvantage is very probably toast.- Area denial is a real thing.  Enough shell-shock (automatic weapons fire, explosives, etc.) in the immediate vicinity of a soldier (human or enemy) can cause them to become Suppressed, which takes away their TU's (no reaction fire from that soldier), and reduces the TU's they get next turn by 50% (no burst fire, probably no grenades, just movement adjustments OR one decent shot).  Heavy weapons and vehicle weapons are wonderful for this, but remember ammo is being counted.- Reaction fire is not solely a function of the reacting soldiers' statistics -- reaction initiative is calculated using (get this) modifiers determined by the weapons and equipment worn by both the active and reactive soldiers, Reaction stats, and *TU's the reacting player has left*.  That doesn't just mean that low TU's result in snap shots; it means that high TU's can result in normal or snap shots, and low TU's can lead to the reactive soldier being unable to respond fast enough even though he technically has enough TU's to take a shot.  In addition, assault weapons actually inflict a reaction penalty on anyone calculating reaction fire against them; carrying a shotgun actually makes it much more likely that you'll get the first shot in a point-blank, room-to-room encounter.Summary:The mechanics of Xenonauts are closer to what I've always wanted X-COM to be.  I'm not in love with the tactical display's graphical quality, but if there's a sequel, I'll look for that to improve.  Meanwhile, the game is a beautiful example of this game type, and the creation and maintenance of it is behavior we enthusiasts should reward by burying the developers in enough money that they decide it would be crazy not to make another one.

												A remake of the original TBS classic X-Com:UFO Defence from the 90s.If you played any of the original Microprose X-Coms and were disappointed with the Firaxis reboot's lack of depth, then Xenonauts will not disappoint.It plays very similar to the original X-COM with some extra polish as you'd expect 20 years later.My favourite aspect is that the game has been opened up to the modding community, and there are some great mods out there that vastly expand the tech trees, maps, equipment etc etc.If you aren't familiar with the original, the game is split into a strategy layer, where you intercept UFOs, build up your bases, equip your troops and aircraft, do research etc, and a turn-based squad combat layer where you investigate crashed and landed UFOs, alien bases, terror sites etc.You never have enough money to do everything you want, and the difficulty ramps up as the invasion progresses. The graphics may seem a bit antiquated, but it's all about the gameplay, and rolling out your strategy for defeating the alien invasion.The ambient music is excellent, and the hours fly by as you get immersed in the game.In my opinion, a must-buy for any fans of the original series, and recommended for any TBS fans.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												What a fond drive down memory lane this game is. For those of us old enough to remember the original X-com, this game will bring back happy and deliciously frustrating memories of that wonderful classic. What the current bearers of the X-com flame have failed to deliver,  the makers of Xenonauts have. We don't need a cheesey 1950's gimmick, or a story line that no one really cares about. We just want to play turn based combat with aliens like we had in the old days. The original X-com was frustrating, easy to get into, yet difficult to master and insanely addictive, Xenonauts is all of that, and more.   This game gives the gamer hours of deep strategic thinking, but without the tedious busy work of many other strategy games. You build your bases, improve your technology, hire and fire researchers, engineers and soldier, try your best to manage your budget (which is more important than one would assume), and all of this while fighting for humanity's very survival, on interesting battlefields all over the globe.     This game is wonderful for those of us who stayed up until dawn in the 90's playing the original, and for younger or newer gamers who want to have that same experience. Take it from an old school PC gamer, if you want all of the fun of the good old DoS days, but with a bit of a graphic and processing revamp, this is it.

Posted: February 19
												Better than the original XCOM? Yes - much less micromanagement, improved air combat & UIBetter than the recent XCOM reboot? Yes - ground combat much closer to the original (more realistic focus on cover and visibility), overall it feels less scripted and linearSo, the definitive version of one of the best strategy games ever made then? Yes!For those unfamiliar with the original XCOM, it's a fairly standard base management game punctuated by possibly the most tense, terrifying turn-based squad elements you'll ever play. It's arguably the greatest game created by two giants of the computer game industry, Julian Gollop & Sid Meier.The only slight criticism for me is that I preferred the droney music of the original which increased the atmosphere. Also, I'm pretty sure they've (rather naughtily) lifted sections of Ennio Morricone's score for The Thing!I also recommend downloading the free Community Edition update for more maps and improved UI. Xenonauts 2 is in production!

Posted: October 31, 2015
												TL;DR = It can be good, even great at times. It can also be horribly frustrating and feels exceptioannly dated for a recent release. For genre veterans its certainly worth a playthrough, but nascent players are better off starting with the recent XCom: EW, Wasteland 2, or Shadowrun: Dragonfall. 7.5/10 Xenonauts follows in the tradition of the original XCom, which focuses on tactical turn-based gameplay coupled with an over-arching strategic layer involving the establishment and maintainence of multiple bases. The strategic portion includes the recruitment of new soldiers, dubbed "xenonauts", as well as the research and production of myriad new technologies. This tech ranges from new weapons and equipment for your xenonauts to new vehicles and enhanced base defenses to help ward off attacks from the alien invaders. The tactical portion is a turn-based affair that utilizes time units (or "TUs") that are used for every action your xenonauts undertake, from movement and reloading to crouching and the use of weapons and medkits. The graphics on display are fairly archaic, and would not have been out-of-place in a mid 90s PC release. While servicable, they are nothing to write home about. The sound has a similar presentation, possessing a distorted quality that lies somewhere between the NES and SNES in terms of depth and range. The gameplay itself is a mixed bag of engaging tactics and uneven difficulty spikes. Each of your xenonauts has a sight cone that allows only the portion of the screen being directly looked at to be uncovered. The rest is shrouded in a shaded fog-of-war where aliens can lurk and undertake actions without being noticed by nearby xenonauts. This sight cone is excpetionally small, and can lead to many instances of "cheap" deaths wherein an alien attacker has clear line of sight on your xenonauts whereas your soldiers cannot see them, despite looking specifically in the direction of the attacker. There are also Chrysallid-type enemies that should be familiar to any veteran XCom player, which will routinely charge from behind the fog-of-war and one-hit kill the closest xenonaut. The type of armor equipped has no bearing on this, as even the top-tier provides absolutely zero protection against one-hit kills from this particular enemy type. The turn-by-turn gameplay is hampered by this and the uneven execution in the RNG (random number generator) system, leading to a "turtling" strategy as the most viable option available to players. Oftentimes your xenonauts will miss the majority of shots during a turn, whereas the aliens appear to benefit from not only increased range, sight, and damage dealt, but also a higher hit incidence. This leads to an understandable level of frustration as the deck feels stacked against you in many encounters, leading to the tried-and-true turtling strategy previously referenced. Players who felt at home with the recent XCom:EW release will likely find the systems used in Xenonauts a bit tedious and challenging in all the wrong ways.Despite these shortfalls, I still recommend Xenonauts to players who enjoyed the XCom series, or other genre staples such as Wasteland and Shadowrun. I would certainly recommend Wasteland 2, Shadowrun: Dragonfall, or XCom: EW over Xenonauts to nascent players of turn-based tactical games due to the latter's steep learning curve and decidedly old-school ambience, mechanics, and presentation. Xenonauts, however, is definitely worth a look for others who have already played those other aforementioned titles and are still looking to scratch their tactical gameplay itch. The strategic layer is deep and engrossing, and the tactical gameplay can be engaging and rewarding when running at its best. Just be aware that the gameplay systems on display feel fairly dated and battles can be tedious affairs that sometimes feel "cheap", but in the end the game as a whole can feel rewarding and become deeply addictive in the way that only the best turn-based strategy games can. Score: 7.5Recommended? YES, with reservations

Posted: September 24, 2014
												Xenonauts is easily the best Turn Based Tactics/Strategy game I've played in long time. I did not play the original XCOM or even the other spinoffs, so this review won't help you if you're looking at it from that perspective.We'll start with the core of the game, combat. Send your elite commandos all over the world to accomplish many different objectives. The combat is turned based, so you have plenty of time to think about your strategy, which is really important because around every corner, you're soldiers could meet their death. The better armed and usually physically stronger alien invaders have a clear advantage. If you're careless, you're dead. Customize your soldiers with gear/weapons to suite the role you want them to play and to suite your tactical preference, but watch out....when they're dead their dead for good along with all the expensive gear you may have equipped them with. You'll face many different types of enemies, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. You'll need to adjust you tactics nearly every mission, depending on what you're facing and what area of the world you're in Urban/Rural/Desert/Arctic. The maps can get a little repetitive, apparently there are not that many, but there are plenty of map mods available or you can make your own.The second part of the game is managing your military, as a whole.  You begin the game facing an enemy who has a clear technological advantage, but thorugh research you can implement Alien technology for your own purposes, but it's expensive and time consuming, so chose wisly. Playing the game on normal, you'll always feel one step behind the aliens as they ramp up their invasion. You'l need to build bases to protect the nations of the world, who are funding you! Let too many aliens thorugh, an you'll lose the nation, loose too many nations game over man.I have about 40 hours in so far and I can highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys thinking tactically or strategically. It's a fun game you can play for 30 minutes at a time or settle in for a good 6 hour marathon. The combat can get a little repretive in the beginning, but as the game progresses I actually started to notice it less. I also downloaded some map mods too.I would give it 4 out of 5 and a must have for lovers of strategy.

Xenonauts is more intuitive and pretty than its predecesor as well as creating the same feeling that you are juggling 9001 balls at once, and are constantly a few poor choices away from total collapse. All in all, the game is a great experience.Although I have not completed the game, just scratched the surface really (I've played three months in-game), I can say for certain that all of the difficulty of the original game is present. Every desicion is vital and it is imperative to really consider the best course of action at all times. If you don't, well, let's say there have been more than a few missions which resulted in complete annihilation of my squad, a terrible loss.The game is also much more faithful to the original than XCOM - ENEMY UNKNOWN, bringing back TU's, much larger squads, and a more complicated geoscape portion of the game. In many respects, though, it improves on the original. The OP Blaster bomb has been removed, the graphics look polished and attractive, and useful/relevant data is more easily accessed.However, I do not mean to say that the game is without faults. For new players to the series, there is hardly and tutorial to introduce them to the many facets of being an international super-secret alien defense force commander. This means the learning curve can be quite steep. Furthermore, the game has some frustrating line of sight issues. Sometimes, I will attempt to move my soldier to firing position, only to discover that the bush I was trying to shoot through might as well be a solid wall. Although over time I have been able to more successfully ascertain what I can and can't do, it has provided a great deal of frustration.All in all, the game is excellent, and in my oppinion more pleasurable to play than the original. (Although the punishing nature of the original adds a bit to the feel. Ironically by making it better it's worse?) Anyway, if you are a fan of strategy games or the original series then I would highly recommend you purchase this game immediately and begin fighting off the extraterrestrial invasion!

Early Access Review
								What can I say about Xenonauts? Well, if you are an oldie such as I. Then you will come to appreciate old classics, like Ufo Alien defence (The old X-com), Jagged Alliance 2 and Panzer General. With the exception of Panzer General, the other two are very similar games. With their core underlying mechanics being grounded in managing a team of soldiers in accomplishing some sort off objective. How is that relevant? Well, for starters. You need to understand what this game is trying to accomplish. And that is replicating an old classic and making it more pleasing to the eye. The 'pleasing to the eye' has already been accomplished by the remake Firaxis has made. So again the question is: What does this game bring? Well it successfully manages to incorporate the core aspects that made the original Xcom so great into a neat little package that is pleasing to the eye and keeps the features rich. 'Feature Rich', that is the key here. Everyone including me loves the new remake of X-com very much, but again, if you are like me. Then you will yearn for the classics. In that case, what better then to play a pseudo remake?

												This game has the same feel as the original X-Com, much more so than the Firaxis remake. While the remake has a small team, they tend to feel more like some sort of action movie super team. In Xenonauts, your team dies. And dies. And dies some more. When you reveal the map, you only increase the tension for those places still hidden, the awareness growing that as you eliminate hiding places you are only closing the range and make it easier for the unknown enemies to perforate your squad with vastly superior firepower. The fire superiority enjoyed by your foes makes no difference to the mission generator, often outnumbering your soldiers as well. You deliberately harden your heart to avoid becoming too attached to that one officer who can move a quarter way across the map and still have time units and accuracy to put a shot through an alien's eye because you know it's just a matter of time until...BANG! And your favorite is a crumpled corpse on the ground, not even identified by name.Then you finish the mission (if it's not a total wipe), go back to base, and hire some more, ready to do it again.

												Xenonauts is in essence an X-COM game after the spirit of the orignal title. I enjoyed the recent Firaxsis XCOMs and, obviously, they are graphically superior to Xenonauts, however Xenonauts has a greater depth of strategic play. Like in the original X-COM, Time Units allow your soldiers to perform complex tasks on the battlefield and this puts paid to my biggest beef with the Firaxsis games. Just like in olden times Soldiers can now shoot then move then crouch and turn, open doors and reload and these actions can be performed in any order as long as there are sufficient time units available to them. No longer will a reload always end my turn and no longer do I need a soldier with a special skill to be able to shoot then move! This alone makes Xenonauts eminently playable for anyone interested in the genre and is one of many areas that the game gets right.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												My first impression of this game is a solid thumbs-up. I think it's a very nice modernization/update to the original X-COM UFO Defense/Enemy Unknown. The general theme seems to be elimination of some of the more mundane "bean counting" aspects of the game and tighter focus on the combat while still providing a reasonable degree of realism and good challenge.I never liked managing soldier Energy, and I actually rather like the elimination of the Workshop Economy because that always seemed a tad cheesy to me. The removal of the rank cap (that is to say, any number of soldiers can be any rank at any given time) is also a very nice concession to organization.The UI is a lot tighter and makes great use of modern resolutions. The air-to-air combat - while occasionally frustrating - does allow an appreciated injection of player skill. My first terror mission - despite being against the game's weakest alien race - was still an unrelenting exercise in creeping dread.I do feel like there is a challenging balance between how much air-to-air vs air-to-ground combat you do, and I'm not sure if that's a game issue or an issue with my playstyle. Either way, I'm having a blast and see myself dumping far too many hours into this game.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												I've played thousands of hours of old X-COM (UFO Defense, Terror From The Deep, Apocalypse), and over 500 hours of Enemy Unknown/Within.  I'm enjoying Xenonauts tremendously.  Details follow, but if you're a fan of the old-school X-COM games, I'm already telling you that you should check this game out.Xenonauts describes itself as a "spiritual successor" to X-COM.  It's important to note that they were very probably not talking about Enemy Unknown/Within; the differences in polish will disappoint you if you're expecting that level of visual quality.  However, as a successor to -old- X-COM (UFO Defense, Terror From The Deep, Apocalypse) it succeeds pretty brilliantly.The look and feel of the Geoscape is very UFOD/TFTD (only much prettier), while the tactical aesthetics are much more like Apocalypse turn-based mode.  Bases have radar ranges determined by the number and quality of detection facilities present, but the range limits are far more visible than in previous games.  This makes it far easier to understand the coverage consequences of base placement. Ship Combat:  X-COM ship fights (even in EU/EW) are like sumo wrestling.  The ships' locations on the field are completely abstracted away, and there are hit percentages simulating mobility, so you see two craft holding relatively still and slugging at each other.  Misses look more like bad aiming than evasive action.In Xenonauts, the ship combat display is a 2D grid wherein momentum and turning radius count.  Weapons have ranges and firing arcs, ammo and fuel count, afterburners are a thing (but see: fuel counts) and missiles have their own maneuverability values.  Defensive maneuvers exist for evasive actions, and a dogfight isn't always 1:1 -- in fact, encounters can get up to 3 vs. 3 in some cases; as UFO's begin to appear with escorts, and fighter squadrons roam in packs daring your interceptors to come out and play, you respond by sending attack groups instead of lone planes.  There are light and heavy interceptor classes, with maneuverability, range and armament consequences.  You can't form an attack group out of craft from more than one base, unfortunately.  I'd have loved to see a rendezvous point system wherein disparate fleets could join up, but ship combat is a fun, complex mini-game in and of itself and a strategy guide could be (and probably has been) written just for that facet of gameplay.  NOTE:  There are -way- more UFO's in the early part of the game than in any iteration of X-COM.  This becomes important during...Ship Combat Aftermath:You can send troops to fight at a crash site, but that's not always an option.  You probably don't have enough strike teams to cover every site where you've shot something down, especially early on when a single Condor is still a match for anything the aliens field.  Rather than letting the sites rot and taking a PR penalty with the nation where they crashed, Xenonauts provides the option to call an airstrike and saturate that area, then send a non-combatant cleanup team to salvage what it can.  This results in a static amount of cash based on the class of crashed craft, and a few recoverable items, but no soldier experience or personnel equipment captures.Soldier Management:  Enemy Unknown/Within introduced the concept of soldier classes; a Rookie, upon promotion to Squaddie, was assigned one of four classes.  That class distinction determined what stats increased when the soldier was promoted, what weapons the soldier was allowed to carry, and what special abilities became available to that soldier as rank increased.  It's a novel concept, but there are downsides.  Class assignment is for life, for one thing, and there's little room for creative misuse of inventory -- you can't load down an Assault trooper with grenades, for instance.  Nonlethal weapons were considered Items rather than weapons in EU/EW, as well, which meant that you had to choose between that and grenades, or extra armor, or whatever else.  It added importance to the range of choices, but only by limiting them. Xenonauts doesn't have classes, but it does allow you to assign a soldier a role.  The main differences are that any role can technically carry any equipment; there are customizable default equipment templates for each role; you can change a soldier's role in the barracks anytime the soldier is on base; and you can create new roles.  Weapon disparity is a little wider, and there is in fact a "laser shotgun" and other mechanics-only nonsense, but in general the strategic and tactical choices you can make in Xenonauts is far wider and more granular than in its ancestors.Tactical Combat:Oh, man.  Where to start.  Quick list of things that don't require explanation:- Stun rockets are a thing.  You get them as soon as you get stun grenades.- You don't have to wait half the game to get stun grenades.- Nonlethal melee weapons exist, and they're weapons -- not some other item class.- All soldiers carry an infinite number of flares!  (But vehicles don't.)- Vision arcs are back.  An unarmored human has a 90-degree effective vision arc.  (Heavy armor can reduce this.)- Cover is not a light switch like in EU/EW, but rather a stack of calculated obstruction percentages like in older X-COM titles.  Stuff that might require some more description:- Range matters a lot.  Different weapons are optimized either for long-range armor-piercing fire, or massive trauma at point-blank range.  You have to make sure you send the right soldier for the right tactical situation, all the time; the aliens are as merciless as they ever were in TFTD, and a soldier caught at a disadvantage is very probably toast.- Area denial is a real thing.  Enough shell-shock (automatic weapons fire, explosives, etc.) in the immediate vicinity of a soldier (human or enemy) can cause them to become Suppressed, which takes away their TU's (no reaction fire from that soldier), and reduces the TU's they get next turn by 50% (no burst fire, probably no grenades, just movement adjustments OR one decent shot).  Heavy weapons and vehicle weapons are wonderful for this, but remember ammo is being counted.- Reaction fire is not solely a function of the reacting soldiers' statistics -- reaction initiative is calculated using (get this) modifiers determined by the weapons and equipment worn by both the active and reactive soldiers, Reaction stats, and *TU's the reacting player has left*.  That doesn't just mean that low TU's result in snap shots; it means that high TU's can result in normal or snap shots, and low TU's can lead to the reactive soldier being unable to respond fast enough even though he technically has enough TU's to take a shot.  In addition, assault weapons actually inflict a reaction penalty on anyone calculating reaction fire against them; carrying a shotgun actually makes it much more likely that you'll get the first shot in a point-blank, room-to-room encounter.Summary:The mechanics of Xenonauts are closer to what I've always wanted X-COM to be.  I'm not in love with the tactical display's graphical quality, but if there's a sequel, I'll look for that to improve.  Meanwhile, the game is a beautiful example of this game type, and the creation and maintenance of it is behavior we enthusiasts should reward by burying the developers in enough money that they decide it would be crazy not to make another one.

												This is one of the best turn based strategy games I have ever played. It is very well made; I have seen no glitchs or bugs, and the controls make miss-clicks a rare occurence. The difficulty scale is great as well. At the lower levels, it is more forgiving for new players yet still really fun. At the higher difficulties, it requires a high level of both stategic and tactical knowledge to survive, providing a very satisfiying challenge that I have not seen since Civ V.The only problems I have with the game is that it does not tell how long some things may take to do, like researching tech and hiring new personel. Posted: June 25, 2014
												I've only played about 15 hours of this so far, and I can safely say that this is, quite simply, one of the best turn based strategy games I've ever played. It's complicated, it's both epic in scope and self contained at the same time, and best of all, it expects you to just man up and deal with it when things go wrong.Essentially, its a straight remake of the 1990's original X-COM: UFO Defence (Or UFO: Enemy Unknown as it was known over here), but with the setting transposed and a few extra features added, such as the ability to airstrike crashes you don't want clear personally, which gets you money and saves time, but you don't get many resources or much soldier experience from it. Also added is a completely new interception system. Once your planes get in range you can direct them as they fly about in the air, until eventually they run out of fuel, ammunition, or everything crashes. It's all pretty awesome.The best part of it though is undoubtedly the vehicles. Unlike the recent XCOM: Enemy Unknown,  your transports can fit a small vehicle such as an armoured car into their loading bay instead of two soldiers. Once researched and built, these give your forces an undeniable edge as they suppress, expose or just otherwise blow the hell out of most of the enemies you encounter, with the tradeoff of limited ammunition and easily destroyed armour at close range.The only downsides I can really think of are a) the map shortage, although apparently there's a downloadable map pack that adds a load of new ones. It hasn't bothered me too much, but it's noticeable and b) you can't turn the camera, so occasionally the isometric veiwpoint obscures things a tad. But these are only minor things.Just get the damn thing already.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												Xenonauts . . . I'm not one who usually supports this new-fangled "early access" gaming craze. Usually. Xenonauts is one of my few exceptions. It's exactly what it claims to be - A complete remake of the original UFO: Enemy Unknown, but with a unique Cold War motif, different aliens, vastly improved graphics (compared to a game from 1994, that's to be expected) and an array of new features and tweaks that make the whole experience feel better and play far more smoothly. What it isn't is a streamlined reboot, ala Firaxis' recent XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within. For better and for worse, this is far more faithful to the original game (read: it's a lot harder to win, and learn how to play the game initially). That's what I wanted, and that's what I got. I couldn't be more pleased, and if this is what you're looking for, then I highly recommend that you stop reading and pick this game up IMMEDIATELY. That said, there are a few things keeping this from being 100% perfect. First, the game just needs a bit more . . . pizazz, for lack of a better word. It lacks an animated intro, a big missing feature compared to either the original UFO or the more recent XCOM. I know most wouldn't consider this a critical thing, but there was always something to booting up UFO and watching the Rob Liefield soldiers jump around firing mini-guns at fist shaking mutons that put you in the mood to do the same on the battlescape, and it's sorely missed when booting up Xenonauts. Obviously something fitting the darker style of 'Nauts would be needed rather than that silliness, but jumping straight into the title menu from the launcher just feels a bit jarring. Plus, one thing the new XCOM definitely nailed was giving the soldiers a lot of personality via little quips and callouts - considering this is a text focused game, it seems like a relatively simple thing that could have been/be added to make battles have just that extra little bit of character that would keep this up with Firaxis' bigger budget reboot. Additionally, this game could really use a tutorial mission or two for first-time players. While these players are obviously not the target demographic (that's fans of the original UFO like myself), the fact that there's nothing makes the transition from UFO neophyte to veteran that much harder. It makes it a bit tougher to recommend to anyone unfamiliar with at least turn-based tactics games and UFO/XCOM in particular. For those in this group that are tempted by the game, I still think you should give this game a shot, just know that you're going to have to have more patience to learn how to play this game than most. After that though, this game is pretty much perfect as far as having an endlessly replayable Military versus Aliens Tactics and Strategy game. Enjoy, and keep watching those skies fellow Xenonauts!

Posted: December 21, 2014
												This game is not fair.Let's get that out of the way right off the bat. If you're looking for something you can play well and have no chance of failing horribly, this is not it. One bad mission, one stroke of bad luck, can send you spinning down the path to destruction.However, there are a great many selling points that keep me coming back to this game; while it isn't fair, if you accept that you will have a good time. This game forces you to think. There will be many times when you will think, "oh, there's probably no aliens there; I can afford to rush or leave it unguarded". Well, if you think that, stop yourself. Mistakes are not dealt with lightly in this game, and rushing is not a luxury you can often take.  Likewise, always have a contingency plan for when you miss. No - scratch that- have three. Because if you leave your team in the hands of someone with a shotgun, and that Andron manages to survive those shots, you just lost a valuable team member, if not two. Leave enough time for your rifleman to pop around the corner and finish him off, or else you will cry. Remember - 70% chance to hit is just an optimistic way to say 30% chance to miss. This game does not like impatience.But it's just so *satisfying*! Blowing your first corvette out of the sky, capturing that first xeno, and clearing out every last alien crash site feels great. And you get the satisfaction of knowing you did it right. Plus this game has all of the options you can possibly want in terms of ground battles. It all works just as you'd expect, and the customization in loadouts along with the options you have in ground battles in terms of strategy makes the game very compelling, and keeps me coming back every time I get frustrated. In the end, no, it's not fair, but there's always something you can do to even the odds, and it all depends on just how much time you're willing to take.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												Xenonauts is a distillation of the X-COM formula to challenge veterans looking for something a little more down-to-earth than Firaxis's XCOM: Enemy Unknown.Success comes in a different package that may not be obvious to UFO Defense alumni. Veterans would think to fill their warchests by raiding landed Supply Ships and mass-producing Laser Cannons. In the Cold War, however, it's up to the funding nations to supply you - you're fighting against both time and budget constraints as you rush to research and manufacture enough new technology to have some hope of staying ahead of the alien invasion, all while keeping your neighbors happy.Ensuring the funding nations remain impressed and satisfied means spending time and resources on the Geoscape and the air game - radar coverage and interceptors. Shooting down UFOs pleases those who pay your bills; failure to effectively react to the disaster tickers is undesirable, the casualty gauge looming overhead as an ever-present reminder of the Xenonauts' reponsibilities.This also acts as something of a de-emphasis on the Battlescape: while you will want to check out new UFOs to add research options, raiding every crash site in every wave will inevitably feel grindy and the monetary rewards would take months to make a difference in the long run. Sending your top dudes to earn a few extra bucks will inevitably backfire when you lose your ace Sniper, forcing you to spend a hundred grand and two weeks to recruit her replacement and manufacture a new weapon and armor. It's much safer to sell the site to the locals, still paying for half a new Plasma Rifle while letting someone else do the dirty work, saving your vets for the new type of UFO due to appear next week.In closing, this is *the* X-COM clone we've been waiting years for. Many games have treid to replicate the formula but Xenonauts has gotten it right like no other.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is a quality revitalization of the original X-COM.  It not only met the high standards set by the 90s classic but also exceeded the benchmark in many ways.  - This is a global war fought by many nations that join in the fight.  Militaries around the world as well as farmers with shotguns will aid the multi-national force in its fight against the alien invasion.  Occassionally they bring down alien crafts (at terrible losses),   Allied units are represented as cops on the street, farmers blasting aliens on the other side of the farm as your troops hunt aliens around haystacks, or national militaries desperately defending the city during terror missions  - Interception missions are extremely fun - take personal control of your interceptors to bait and flank enemy crafts once your squadron catches up to an enemy flight (it could be a battleshield escorted by two fighters, or just a lone scout) - this minigame is many times more fun than X-COM's interception mission.  - Your soldiers earn medals for performing extraordinary tasks - the medals in turn boost their stats- Many weapons to choose from - riot shields (wield one with a pistol), shotguns, rifles, sniper rifles, RPGs, HMGs, researched alien technologies, even a TANK that will eventually look like a real tank (upon further research).  Who doesn't want to use a tank to blow away aliens?  In X-COM games, the tank is always a tiny robo-craft that look gimpy... here we have a real tank!  - Addressed many short-comings in the original X-COM game.  You can now fly the troop transport to multiple crash sites, direct interceptors to target one group of enemy after another (assuming enough ammo and fuel left).  - It is a challenging but highly rewarding game.  It is fair (none of that enemy "spawning" behavior in X-COM Enemy Unknown), but it is tough.  I would rather have a tough game that is fair than an easy game with funky game logics. I am an avid X-COM player: 5 playthroughs in the original X-COM, 1 playthrough of TFTD (ok that was torture), 1 playthrough for Apocalypse, 1 playthrough in X-COM EU.  I am proud to say that Xenonaut has won me over as the quality spiritual successor that I have always been looking for.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												I actually deleted my first review of this game, in light of my opinion on it changing considerably.Do I recommend the game, still? Mildly, yes. Do I like it? Yeah! Do I LOVE it? No, no I do not.I bought this game mostly because X-Com Classic is incredibly old and boy oh boy did I not want to have to deal with that god forsaken UI, yet at the same time, I wanted to see what was missing from XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within. So, I bought this game.The game developers seem to have made numerous changes to the game, from X-Com. They are all based on good intentions, but... well, you know what they say about good intentions. For one, the developers removed weapons like Blaster Launchers. While that's all well and good, the developers also decided to cut Psychic Powers entirely out of the game. It sounded like a good idea, at first (Mind Control was pretty broken, come on, guys), it seriously neuters the game's variety. As the game progresses, missions start to feel the same, and some of them drag on way too long. After a few months into the campaign, save for some new alien species appearing, there was very little difference in overall gameplay. And because the missions are so dry and repetitive, it quickly starts to feel like a damn grind. Now, one could say the missions in XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within were also repetitive -- and I won't lie to you, they became rather tiresome (especially in the lackluster endgame). But Enemy Unknown had many mechanics that made it enjoyable, most importantly the perks that each soldier got. Yeah it may not be realistic but honestly I would much rather have perks, than have every single soldier be completely interchangeable -- and that's what it's like in Xenonauts. Every soldier is basically the same. Every mission is the same. Without things like perks and abilities, combat gets boring FAST. Oh, and you don't profit from selling alien items, like you did in X-com. Again, balance issues and good intentions. But the economy in this game is already quite stressful. Oh, and also, not being able to make a profit selling weapons capable of hurting aliens to a world that is in desperate need of them makes NO GOD DAMN SENSE! So how do you make money? You grind your balls off raiding every UFO that touches Terran dirt, which is what makes the combat gameplay grow stale!Man, you know, thinking about it -- I honestly have no idea if I can recommend this game. It's pretty moddable, but even mods only do so much. The combat is kind of nice, though. Reminds me of Fallout.I give it a cautious and confused recommendation, because despite its flaws, I can't bring myself to hate the game. Also, many of the game's features can literally be tinkered with simply by opening the .xml files in OpenOffice or something -- which I personally did to end that profit nonsense mentioned above.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												Summary: High-quality clone of the original X-Com: Enemy Unknown (1994).Positive: Its X-Com with modern features draped in a nice Cold War setting. The geoscape and battlescape are here with almost nothing left out (see below). The writing is actually a standout, reading the research reports was a small joy. Everything is presented in a way that is plausible in a late '70s timeline. The conclusions the science teams come away with are believable works of good fiction. I would love to provide an excerpt for your enjoyment here, but its too good to potentially spoil anything. There is also a bit of humor with a minor rivalry between the science and engineering departments. Speaking of research, as the game progresses and the Xenonaut program continues it's scientific advance, the graphics of your base screens update with the newfound technology; its a nice touch. Non-Xenonaut friendly forces also gain some of the technology you discover over time; neat! The game is also moddable. Negative: A few bugs: nothing too major, but there was one glitch that locked the game. This error only happend once over a 50+ hour campaign. There are some graphical errors when minimizing the game. Further visual glitches when aliens throw grenades; sometimes doubling in size until the animation completes, or appearing to throw twice in succession. There is a type of combat that doesn't involve traditional weaponry that is notablely missing from the game. The aliens still have it, but unlike every other X-Com clone the human forces simply cannot gain it... ever. Personally, I would have preferred for this type of combat to be rebalanced rather than removed from the game. There are only two ways to fight back against this "weapon" and neither one is reliable. There are very few maps in the battlescape. You'll end up on the same slightly-altered variations endlessly. There is a popular mod that fixes this. The infamous "95%-chance-to-hit-but-still-somehow-misses" RNG is still alive and well here. The aliens also get to throw grenades in some situations in which you cannot ("100% block"). Smoke Grenages are heavily nerfed, almost to the point of being useless. They were too powerful in the original for sure, but here they only last three turns (at best) and only work against a few types of aliens.The geoscape UFO activity happens all at once instead of being spaced out. Basically, the aliens coordinate one big "assault-of-the-week" every few days without variation. It would have been better to keep the old style of individual missions rather than this approach; it feels too synthetic.Overall: 8/10, I can't remember the last time a game has kept me playing in one sitting as long as this one. I felt like a kid again playing this wonderful game. Great job developers! With mods this is a nine out of ten game.

Posted: March 11
												Bought this game a while ago and thought it was time to write a review.If you love the old UFO/XCOM games (the MSDOS ones from Microsoft) you will love this game. It is VERY similar comapred to those classics, with of course imrpoved graphics and gameplay.Everything you loved in the old games is here..and more....or better,sometimes both.The intercepting of an ufo for example. Now you can control andgive directions to your fighters,where to fly,to evade,afterburner etc. Its possible to shoot down a large UFO, by using inferiour/outdated crafts and weapons, by just apllying a good strategy. Some UFOS have escort crafts, some ufos need rockets(torpedos) to make them land. There are alot of options.The actual isometric ground combat is much harder than in the old Xcoms. The aliens are more deadly and smarter than the Mircoprose ones. It requires care and patience to surivive the first missions without casualties. In general, the learning curve for thsi game is steeper in every aspect. The financial part is very challening. To keep your bases running and build new fighters and weapons or armor is costly. Even the base locations took me several starts to really get a cost efficient coverage of the globe. Of course all the other game aspects from the classics are here. Base construction, research, building items, improving your squad etc are all here...but as i mentiond just better polished.I played the early 2000 UFO games,which were realtime and hated them. I played the 2k Xcom and never really liked it. It looks flashy, but the gameplay is just boring and stale. It does not feel grand and very limited.Xenonauts gives me all the freedom i want ...and it makes me pay for it, if i make poor decisions....but i love it.

Posted: February 25, 2015
												One of my men panicked and shot my machine gunner so next turn my rifleman promptly turned around and shot him. I don't have time for cowards in my xco... errr xenonauts.----see proper review below----This game... IS FANTASTIC! I own all x-coms thanks to a wonderful Steam sale (PRAISE LORD GABEN) and after playing openxcom (it's a mod that overhauls the 1993 xcom) for over 600 hours I can clearly say THIS is the proper sequel to that game. Basically it's a pretty remake of the original xcom ufo defense from 1993. No fancy voice acting, no 3d graphics, nothing shiny. Xenonauts takes place in the 1970's at the height of the cold war so the world is ready to blow itself up four times over so yes I love how the graphics are dry and bleak and bland because it makes the player feel this constant tension even when your at the base. The lore is fantastic. Autoposies no longer take days but your scientists automatically do them and give you a report you have to READ! *gasp* Yes read. Like I said before there's no lady screaming at you "COMMANDER TO THE RESEARCH LABS" anymore. It's just you, errie music, and your silent soldiers who are willing to die at a moments notice if their commander orders them to.Action points are back! YESSSS! If you don't like manually checking your corners and you think your soldiers should have vision 360 degrees around them at all times then you won't like the fact that when clearing a room you have to turn left, turn right, turn forward, and clear the room step by step by step. It's much slower than firaxis's xcom and i like xenonauts much more because of it.And vehicles that actually do stuff! SHIV's? Pfft. How bout a small tank?And mods! MODS MODS MODS MODS MODS! There's not many out there as of right now but the ones that are out there are FANTASTIC such as Fire in the Hole which makes UFO's breachable in certain spots so if the front door isn't an option make you own door.In short the new xcom's are just toooo dumbed down for me and xenonauts gives me the "pre♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; feeling on missions that the original xcom did. Maybe not to the point of where your walking around with your hands on your butt, but it's still that ol familiar "should I go check that corner of the map even though its really small but an alien could be waiting to shoot my guy in the back if i don't go check it damn it there's an alien there wtf am i gonna do now" feeling.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												Xenonauts is easily the best Turn Based Tactics/Strategy game I've played in long time. I did not play the original XCOM or even the other spinoffs, so this review won't help you if you're looking at it from that perspective.We'll start with the core of the game, combat. Send your elite commandos all over the world to accomplish many different objectives. The combat is turned based, so you have plenty of time to think about your strategy, which is really important because around every corner, you're soldiers could meet their death. The better armed and usually physically stronger alien invaders have a clear advantage. If you're careless, you're dead. Customize your soldiers with gear/weapons to suite the role you want them to play and to suite your tactical preference, but watch out....when they're dead their dead for good along with all the expensive gear you may have equipped them with. You'll face many different types of enemies, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. You'll need to adjust you tactics nearly every mission, depending on what you're facing and what area of the world you're in Urban/Rural/Desert/Arctic. The maps can get a little repetitive, apparently there are not that many, but there are plenty of map mods available or you can make your own.The second part of the game is managing your military, as a whole.  You begin the game facing an enemy who has a clear technological advantage, but thorugh research you can implement Alien technology for your own purposes, but it's expensive and time consuming, so chose wisly. Playing the game on normal, you'll always feel one step behind the aliens as they ramp up their invasion. You'l need to build bases to protect the nations of the world, who are funding you! Let too many aliens thorugh, an you'll lose the nation, loose too many nations game over man.I have about 40 hours in so far and I can highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys thinking tactically or strategically. It's a fun game you can play for 30 minutes at a time or settle in for a good 6 hour marathon. The combat can get a little repretive in the beginning, but as the game progresses I actually started to notice it less. I also downloaded some map mods too.I would give it 4 out of 5 and a must have for lovers of strategy.
