Posted: October 31, 2015
												TL;DR = It can be good, even great at times. It can also be horribly frustrating and feels exceptioannly dated for a recent release. For genre veterans its certainly worth a playthrough, but nascent players are better off starting with the recent XCom: EW, Wasteland 2, or Shadowrun: Dragonfall. 7.5/10 Xenonauts follows in the tradition of the original XCom, which focuses on tactical turn-based gameplay coupled with an over-arching strategic layer involving the establishment and maintainence of multiple bases. The strategic portion includes the recruitment of new soldiers, dubbed "xenonauts", as well as the research and production of myriad new technologies. This tech ranges from new weapons and equipment for your xenonauts to new vehicles and enhanced base defenses to help ward off attacks from the alien invaders. The tactical portion is a turn-based affair that utilizes time units (or "TUs") that are used for every action your xenonauts undertake, from movement and reloading to crouching and the use of weapons and medkits. The graphics on display are fairly archaic, and would not have been out-of-place in a mid 90s PC release. While servicable, they are nothing to write home about. The sound has a similar presentation, possessing a distorted quality that lies somewhere between the NES and SNES in terms of depth and range. The gameplay itself is a mixed bag of engaging tactics and uneven difficulty spikes. Each of your xenonauts has a sight cone that allows only the portion of the screen being directly looked at to be uncovered. The rest is shrouded in a shaded fog-of-war where aliens can lurk and undertake actions without being noticed by nearby xenonauts. This sight cone is excpetionally small, and can lead to many instances of "cheap" deaths wherein an alien attacker has clear line of sight on your xenonauts whereas your soldiers cannot see them, despite looking specifically in the direction of the attacker. There are also Chrysallid-type enemies that should be familiar to any veteran XCom player, which will routinely charge from behind the fog-of-war and one-hit kill the closest xenonaut. The type of armor equipped has no bearing on this, as even the top-tier provides absolutely zero protection against one-hit kills from this particular enemy type. The turn-by-turn gameplay is hampered by this and the uneven execution in the RNG (random number generator) system, leading to a "turtling" strategy as the most viable option available to players. Oftentimes your xenonauts will miss the majority of shots during a turn, whereas the aliens appear to benefit from not only increased range, sight, and damage dealt, but also a higher hit incidence. This leads to an understandable level of frustration as the deck feels stacked against you in many encounters, leading to the tried-and-true turtling strategy previously referenced. Players who felt at home with the recent XCom:EW release will likely find the systems used in Xenonauts a bit tedious and challenging in all the wrong ways.Despite these shortfalls, I still recommend Xenonauts to players who enjoyed the XCom series, or other genre staples such as Wasteland and Shadowrun. I would certainly recommend Wasteland 2, Shadowrun: Dragonfall, or XCom: EW over Xenonauts to nascent players of turn-based tactical games due to the latter's steep learning curve and decidedly old-school ambience, mechanics, and presentation. Xenonauts, however, is definitely worth a look for others who have already played those other aforementioned titles and are still looking to scratch their tactical gameplay itch. The strategic layer is deep and engrossing, and the tactical gameplay can be engaging and rewarding when running at its best. Just be aware that the gameplay systems on display feel fairly dated and battles can be tedious affairs that sometimes feel "cheap", but in the end the game as a whole can feel rewarding and become deeply addictive in the way that only the best turn-based strategy games can. Score: 7.5Recommended? YES, with reservations

												THIS was the X-COM 'sequel' I was hoping for.  I absolutely love this game.I love the 70/80's style graphics.  It really adds a nice feel to the game.  They are finely detailed, not intentionally dated as seems to be the trend with indie games now a days.  And anyone who has tried modding the unit graphics knows what sort of attention was put into these!That brings me to my favorite thing about this:  Modding!  Man, you can change virtually anything and everything in the game if you know where to look.  Add entire tiers of weapons or armor, including their 'pedia pages.  Change the stats on weapons, how your guys level up, you name it!  I even created a dart gun mod that is currently over on their official webpage.I think the biggest con, if I had to pick one, is that it is done in the Diner Dash engine.  This apparently severely limited what the developer could do with it.  But even with that limitation, Chris still came through with an absolutely stunning game.If you like the old X-COM games, You should enjoy this.  It is well worth the money, I promise!

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I've only played about 15 hours of this so far, and I can safely say that this is, quite simply, one of the best turn based strategy games I've ever played. It's complicated, it's both epic in scope and self contained at the same time, and best of all, it expects you to just man up and deal with it when things go wrong.Essentially, its a straight remake of the 1990's original X-COM: UFO Defence (Or UFO: Enemy Unknown as it was known over here), but with the setting transposed and a few extra features added, such as the ability to airstrike crashes you don't want clear personally, which gets you money and saves time, but you don't get many resources or much soldier experience from it. Also added is a completely new interception system. Once your planes get in range you can direct them as they fly about in the air, until eventually they run out of fuel, ammunition, or everything crashes. It's all pretty awesome.The best part of it though is undoubtedly the vehicles. Unlike the recent XCOM: Enemy Unknown,  your transports can fit a small vehicle such as an armoured car into their loading bay instead of two soldiers. Once researched and built, these give your forces an undeniable edge as they suppress, expose or just otherwise blow the hell out of most of the enemies you encounter, with the tradeoff of limited ammunition and easily destroyed armour at close range.The only downsides I can really think of are a) the map shortage, although apparently there's a downloadable map pack that adds a load of new ones. It hasn't bothered me too much, but it's noticeable and b) you can't turn the camera, so occasionally the isometric veiwpoint obscures things a tad. But these are only minor things.Just get the damn thing already.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												Xenonauts . . . I'm not one who usually supports this new-fangled "early access" gaming craze. Usually. Xenonauts is one of my few exceptions. It's exactly what it claims to be - A complete remake of the original UFO: Enemy Unknown, but with a unique Cold War motif, different aliens, vastly improved graphics (compared to a game from 1994, that's to be expected) and an array of new features and tweaks that make the whole experience feel better and play far more smoothly. What it isn't is a streamlined reboot, ala Firaxis' recent XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within. For better and for worse, this is far more faithful to the original game (read: it's a lot harder to win, and learn how to play the game initially). That's what I wanted, and that's what I got. I couldn't be more pleased, and if this is what you're looking for, then I highly recommend that you stop reading and pick this game up IMMEDIATELY. That said, there are a few things keeping this from being 100% perfect. First, the game just needs a bit more . . . pizazz, for lack of a better word. It lacks an animated intro, a big missing feature compared to either the original UFO or the more recent XCOM. I know most wouldn't consider this a critical thing, but there was always something to booting up UFO and watching the Rob Liefield soldiers jump around firing mini-guns at fist shaking mutons that put you in the mood to do the same on the battlescape, and it's sorely missed when booting up Xenonauts. Obviously something fitting the darker style of 'Nauts would be needed rather than that silliness, but jumping straight into the title menu from the launcher just feels a bit jarring. Plus, one thing the new XCOM definitely nailed was giving the soldiers a lot of personality via little quips and callouts - considering this is a text focused game, it seems like a relatively simple thing that could have been/be added to make battles have just that extra little bit of character that would keep this up with Firaxis' bigger budget reboot. Additionally, this game could really use a tutorial mission or two for first-time players. While these players are obviously not the target demographic (that's fans of the original UFO like myself), the fact that there's nothing makes the transition from UFO neophyte to veteran that much harder. It makes it a bit tougher to recommend to anyone unfamiliar with at least turn-based tactics games and UFO/XCOM in particular. For those in this group that are tempted by the game, I still think you should give this game a shot, just know that you're going to have to have more patience to learn how to play this game than most. After that though, this game is pretty much perfect as far as having an endlessly replayable Military versus Aliens Tactics and Strategy game. Enjoy, and keep watching those skies fellow Xenonauts!

The added features such as air-combat really make the game epic. The AI has been written to perfection, no longer are the aliens half asleep dozing about. However a small improvement to suggest would be to tweak the reaction firering mechanics as currently it feels like saving TUs for it is a bit pointless

Posted: August 22, 2014
												A remake of the original TBS classic X-Com:UFO Defence from the 90s.If you played any of the original Microprose X-Coms and were disappointed with the Firaxis reboot's lack of depth, then Xenonauts will not disappoint.It plays very similar to the original X-COM with some extra polish as you'd expect 20 years later.My favourite aspect is that the game has been opened up to the modding community, and there are some great mods out there that vastly expand the tech trees, maps, equipment etc etc.If you aren't familiar with the original, the game is split into a strategy layer, where you intercept UFOs, build up your bases, equip your troops and aircraft, do research etc, and a turn-based squad combat layer where you investigate crashed and landed UFOs, alien bases, terror sites etc.You never have enough money to do everything you want, and the difficulty ramps up as the invasion progresses. The graphics may seem a bit antiquated, but it's all about the gameplay, and rolling out your strategy for defeating the alien invasion.The ambient music is excellent, and the hours fly by as you get immersed in the game.In my opinion, a must-buy for any fans of the original series, and recommended for any TBS fans.

Posted: September 7, 2014
												Spiffing! As everyone knows, unlike the reimaged XCom that came out recently, this Xenonauts is an update of the original Xcom. And it's very well done. You have the base management. Placing bases for their radar coverage, with hangars to send ships out to intercept alien craft. Then send in your landing vehicle for your troops and maybe a buggy to go round gunning down the survivors of the crashed alien craft. Could also be going in to a Terror Mission. To fight off the aliens and save what locals you can and maintain relations with the nation so terrorised. Might be the alliens attack your base and gun batteries you've chosen to build may or may not be enough, and then have to clear your base of aliens the hard way. Could be you discover a base the aliens have set up. Going in to clear it room by room.The base management leaves a lot of room for playstyles and mistakes. Setting up labs and workrooms for scientists to research alien tech and engineers to make new toys. So many toys. Found it best to keep the enhanced workshop action at the base your soldiers come home to, other bases wouldn't have access to the alien materials unless you start sending parcels of items back and forth. Extra radar arrays widen the coverage of each base, and extra bases spaced around the planets are essential in ensuring few alien craft get to run amok without you sending in your ships.When you do that, you can choose to send 1-3 ships all together. So that requires you building hangers at various bases around the world too. When  your ships catch an alien craft it gives you a % of success for an automated dogfight, but you can elect to go in to manually direct the aero-action. When an alien craft is downed you can send in your foot troops, or, just have an airstrike deal alien stragglers. Youll get a bt of money that way but no chance of acquiring fancy alien tech to play with. The land battle is as ever a turn based game.  Your mooks have a number of points they can spend on moving, kneeling, turning, shooting, luzzing grenades, equipping the med pack from your backpack to use on a wounded ally, or battering an alien over the head with a stun rod. With shooting there's a few choices in how accurate you're prepared to be, more accuracy costs more points. Cover reduces the ahcne of success while kneeling raises it. You could leave your mook with points unspent in which case they're stood there prepared to fire at any alien bugger that hoves into view. Their reflexes stat comes into play then, whether they get a shot off before the alien does. Stats like those and strength (covers how much you can carry without movement penalties) and bravery are automatically improved when they're used. So it really hurts if someone dies. If a xenonaut is hit and hurt they'll spend some time in the med-bay you built. Dead ones, there's a slim chance they recover, less so the more they're hurt.It seems rather well designed. The learning curve is about right. The arms race between you and the aliens is in your favour if you get on top of R&D early on and keep it flowing. One of your more beloved xenonauts taking a powerful hit and dying can really sting though. You could be brave and suck it up, or go back to a previous save point. It quite a moddable game in regards "numbers", so you could adjust such things as the amount of money here or there if you want. It wouldn't affect the current game, just the next one started.

Posted: August 25, 2014
												This is a really good game, and in many regards, this is indeed XCOM's true successor.- The tactical game feels a lot like the original, with the same dilemmas and cold sweats, but with a nice gameplay refresh integrating modern concepts such as cover. It is a real success; the general way you play the game is very faithful to the original game, but it is significantly deeper and more interesting.- The same can be said for the strategic game. The general feeling is the same as in the original game, but it is much, much more complex and the game has little forgiveness for people who make wrong choices.- The interception minigame is really nice. There are a few problems that should be solved (some dogfights which have good success chances on autoresolve are actually unwinnable if you try to play them) but it adds something that had not been attempted or done right by any of the previous XCOM-inspired games.- The general cold war atmosphere is nice and the flavour text (research reports, news ticker, etc.) fleshes out the universe nicely. All the text-based universe description is a real success.- The music is good, and the sound effects are good too.Now a few criticisms:- The graphics. Seriously. The geoscape and base layout screens are OK. The background art (research/engineering screens, etc.) is decent, even though it lacks something. Everything else is horrible. The aliens, the equipment, most of the armours and almost everything in the tactical game is ugly, bland and unremarkable. I would go as far as saying that I prefer the visuals from the 1994 game in their VGA splendor. They are pixelated and often cheesy in a 90s SF way, but they have a character that is completely absent here. Even the recent X-COM: Enemy Unknown, which is much more bland and soulless than Xenonauts in many ways, easily wins this match.- The UFO missions eventually become repetitive. True, you can airstrike crash sites, but it is often not an economically viable option, and the combination of low resources, quite slow research and high enemy activity leads to phases of the game where you have nothing else to do than wait for your research/engineering projects to eventually complete while playing non-stop difficult missions which look a lot like one another, have each the potential to wipe your team, and do not bring you any reward except some cash and the chance to live another day. This is somehow realistic, but not so funny.- This is not a true Linux game: the developers juste made special efforts to make the game run correctly with Wine. This is not nothing, and I don't blame the developers, but Wine compliance is not the same at all as a native GNU/Linux version, and I find it misleading and disappoingint to see it listed as a "Linux game" on Steam. (And even more so since you can't even install the Linux Wine port through Steam) This is one of the reasons why I so readily bought this game, and although it is a fine game, on that point I feel cheated.

Posted: July 7, 2016
												To give you an idea of what this game is like, I wrote this:You are the last man in your squad, Reapers have zombified every human in the city and to your dismay one of them pursuing you. You are too busy looking behind you to realize you have been backed into an alley,  you look behind you once again to see your adversary facing you, Snappinng It's massive mouth with hundreds of incredibly sharp teeth. You can feel its hot breath against your skin, you think it is the end, and put your rifle's muzzle against your neck. But your luck changes, and you realize the reaper has exhausted their time unit supply. You lower the gun and point it at the reaper, "95% it will hit." you think to yourself. You point your rifle at the reaper's head, and close your eyes. "A 95% chance I will live." You smile and pull the trigger. You hear the gun fire and feel the recoil of the bullet leaving the chamber, you open your eyes and hope to see a headless reaper corpse in front of you. Unfortunate as it is, you missed the shot and the reaper in front of you still has a head and still wants to kill you and use your body as a vessel for its parasitic spawn.10/10 would lose "Pvt. John Mctiggles" exactly like that again.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Xenonauts is in essence an X-COM game after the spirit of the orignal title. I enjoyed the recent Firaxsis XCOMs and, obviously, they are graphically superior to Xenonauts, however Xenonauts has a greater depth of strategic play. Like in the original X-COM, Time Units allow your soldiers to perform complex tasks on the battlefield and this puts paid to my biggest beef with the Firaxsis games. Just like in olden times Soldiers can now shoot then move then crouch and turn, open doors and reload and these actions can be performed in any order as long as there are sufficient time units available to them. No longer will a reload always end my turn and no longer do I need a soldier with a special skill to be able to shoot then move! This alone makes Xenonauts eminently playable for anyone interested in the genre and is one of many areas that the game gets right.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Holy crap, this game, smells and looks like the original X-com, but it looks like the original X-com we remember playing with our rose tinted glasses of the past, in laymans terms, that means that the original game didn't look as good as this, but  we'd like to think it did. Couple this with mod support and the outstanding community edition that is available through steam, and this game is a winner winner, chicken dinner. You can play through this game however you want to, do you brink a vehicle or two extra xeonauts? do you bring heavy or light guns? just grenades? pretty much any strategy works on the battlefield if your patient enough to make it work. most games these days hold your hand, this one will help you at the start but just like a parent teaching their child to ride a bike you'll soon notice those hands on your back are gone, how long have they been gone? you don't know because this game is easy to learn, but very hard to master.There will be times when this game will make you want to rage quit, thats normal, thats called building a connection with your troops and then some alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with his plasma power sniper rifle gets a lucky shot and blow out their head/chest cavity with a bolt of plasma, thats what happens when your going up against superior tech. Your only way to win is to get tactical.Although iron man mode isn't the only way to play this game, its singleplayer you play however you want to play, want to load a save game everytime something goes wrong? you can do, its called learning. my first playthrough was somewhat like that, i took my fair share of losses, and even with repeated reloading, the game was still very challenging. My second playthrough is shaping up to be a much tougher, and rougher challenge without the reloading. And if i can justify giving this game another run through you can justify playing it if you have any love of tactical games. ( especially if it is on sale like it is right now!)

Posted: December 21, 2014
												This game is not fair.Let's get that out of the way right off the bat. If you're looking for something you can play well and have no chance of failing horribly, this is not it. One bad mission, one stroke of bad luck, can send you spinning down the path to destruction.However, there are a great many selling points that keep me coming back to this game; while it isn't fair, if you accept that you will have a good time. This game forces you to think. There will be many times when you will think, "oh, there's probably no aliens there; I can afford to rush or leave it unguarded". Well, if you think that, stop yourself. Mistakes are not dealt with lightly in this game, and rushing is not a luxury you can often take.  Likewise, always have a contingency plan for when you miss. No - scratch that- have three. Because if you leave your team in the hands of someone with a shotgun, and that Andron manages to survive those shots, you just lost a valuable team member, if not two. Leave enough time for your rifleman to pop around the corner and finish him off, or else you will cry. Remember - 70% chance to hit is just an optimistic way to say 30% chance to miss. This game does not like impatience.But it's just so *satisfying*! Blowing your first corvette out of the sky, capturing that first xeno, and clearing out every last alien crash site feels great. And you get the satisfaction of knowing you did it right. Plus this game has all of the options you can possibly want in terms of ground battles. It all works just as you'd expect, and the customization in loadouts along with the options you have in ground battles in terms of strategy makes the game very compelling, and keeps me coming back every time I get frustrated. In the end, no, it's not fair, but there's always something you can do to even the odds, and it all depends on just how much time you're willing to take.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												I actually deleted my first review of this game, in light of my opinion on it changing considerably.Do I recommend the game, still? Mildly, yes. Do I like it? Yeah! Do I LOVE it? No, no I do not.I bought this game mostly because X-Com Classic is incredibly old and boy oh boy did I not want to have to deal with that god forsaken UI, yet at the same time, I wanted to see what was missing from XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within. So, I bought this game.The game developers seem to have made numerous changes to the game, from X-Com. They are all based on good intentions, but... well, you know what they say about good intentions. For one, the developers removed weapons like Blaster Launchers. While that's all well and good, the developers also decided to cut Psychic Powers entirely out of the game. It sounded like a good idea, at first (Mind Control was pretty broken, come on, guys), it seriously neuters the game's variety. As the game progresses, missions start to feel the same, and some of them drag on way too long. After a few months into the campaign, save for some new alien species appearing, there was very little difference in overall gameplay. And because the missions are so dry and repetitive, it quickly starts to feel like a damn grind. Now, one could say the missions in XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within were also repetitive -- and I won't lie to you, they became rather tiresome (especially in the lackluster endgame). But Enemy Unknown had many mechanics that made it enjoyable, most importantly the perks that each soldier got. Yeah it may not be realistic but honestly I would much rather have perks, than have every single soldier be completely interchangeable -- and that's what it's like in Xenonauts. Every soldier is basically the same. Every mission is the same. Without things like perks and abilities, combat gets boring FAST. Oh, and you don't profit from selling alien items, like you did in X-com. Again, balance issues and good intentions. But the economy in this game is already quite stressful. Oh, and also, not being able to make a profit selling weapons capable of hurting aliens to a world that is in desperate need of them makes NO GOD DAMN SENSE! So how do you make money? You grind your balls off raiding every UFO that touches Terran dirt, which is what makes the combat gameplay grow stale!Man, you know, thinking about it -- I honestly have no idea if I can recommend this game. It's pretty moddable, but even mods only do so much. The combat is kind of nice, though. Reminds me of Fallout.I give it a cautious and confused recommendation, because despite its flaws, I can't bring myself to hate the game. Also, many of the game's features can literally be tinkered with simply by opening the .xml files in OpenOffice or something -- which I personally did to end that profit nonsense mentioned above.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												Xenonauts is a distillation of the X-COM formula to challenge veterans looking for something a little more down-to-earth than Firaxis's XCOM: Enemy Unknown.Success comes in a different package that may not be obvious to UFO Defense alumni. Veterans would think to fill their warchests by raiding landed Supply Ships and mass-producing Laser Cannons. In the Cold War, however, it's up to the funding nations to supply you - you're fighting against both time and budget constraints as you rush to research and manufacture enough new technology to have some hope of staying ahead of the alien invasion, all while keeping your neighbors happy.Ensuring the funding nations remain impressed and satisfied means spending time and resources on the Geoscape and the air game - radar coverage and interceptors. Shooting down UFOs pleases those who pay your bills; failure to effectively react to the disaster tickers is undesirable, the casualty gauge looming overhead as an ever-present reminder of the Xenonauts' reponsibilities.This also acts as something of a de-emphasis on the Battlescape: while you will want to check out new UFOs to add research options, raiding every crash site in every wave will inevitably feel grindy and the monetary rewards would take months to make a difference in the long run. Sending your top dudes to earn a few extra bucks will inevitably backfire when you lose your ace Sniper, forcing you to spend a hundred grand and two weeks to recruit her replacement and manufacture a new weapon and armor. It's much safer to sell the site to the locals, still paying for half a new Plasma Rifle while letting someone else do the dirty work, saving your vets for the new type of UFO due to appear next week.In closing, this is *the* X-COM clone we've been waiting years for. Many games have treid to replicate the formula but Xenonauts has gotten it right like no other.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												The best modern remake of X-com: UFO Defense and Terror From The Deep. It's the one most faithful to the old games.+ Improved interface/GUI, e.g. aiming interface is more like Jagged Alliance: right-click to improve accuracy.+ New air combat system that's much more fun.+ Eerie/Horror soundtrack similar to original games.+ Ground combat requires new tactics, e.g. grenades were nerfed, there is a suppression system.+ As in X-Com Apocalypse, you need to require live aliens and explosives destroy aliens bodies and equipment. So, it's more challenging to get live aliens.+ Improved graphics. Xenonauts and aliens animations are really fluid.+ So far (3rd month in the game), you can't seem to make money by creating items like in the old games. Your main source of income are the funding from the nations. Might be a minus for you.+ Quickstart guide and in-game tooltips lets you get started playing in no time.+ Geoscape now shows UFO events throughout the world, so you don't need to mess around with the cumbersome UFO Activity Graph like in the older games.+ Devs are still updating the game.+ The story and xenopedia entries are very well written.+ You can now air strike a UFO crash site for money, if you don't want/can't do the mission at the moment.+ Soundtrack and other goodies are included in the extras folder.+ Game is easily moddable.+/- Some parts of the game were simplified, but overall it still retains the essence of the original X-Com games. Some of those simplifications were: unlimited *basic* ammo/weapons, a single warehouse holds unlimited items, unlimited flares for night missions, buildings like missile defenses and some items like medkits are auto upgraded after research is done, alien items are sold/destroyed/stored automatically after a ground mission, soldiers don't have an energy meter.- Can't throw equipment to teammates. Have to drop it on the ground and have the other one pick it up.- I found the machinegun to be really useless.- Downed UFOs can only be entered through main door. You can't blow up any part of the hull, however you can still blow up the door.- Apparently, there is no incendiary ammo, particle disturbance grenade and particle sensor.Overall, the game is great! A must buy for X-Com fans.

Chaos and blood shed under fire and brimstone at it's finest in turn based combat. All things in the map are destructable. Posted: November 23, 2016
												I have never played any of the previous XCOM games. I just want people who also haven't to know that about me up front.My experience with Xenonauts has been excellent. This is an addictive game that will have you hooked with that 'JUST ONE MORE TURN' addiction that all good games have. I highly recommend this game to any turn-based strategy fan. Before I go any further, if you decide to play this game, you NEED to play it on Ironman mode; that's what makes this game so great. It's a mode where you aren't allowed to save-scum, so all of your actions, and mistakes, are permanent.I consider myself fairly well versed on turn-based strategy games. I'm a 31 year old gamer who has very fond childhood memories of early strategy games like Shining Force, Dark Wizard, Final Fantasy Tactics, OgreBattle, Civilization, Heros of M&M, as well as more modern strategy games like Disgaea. I enjoyed and still enjoy every single one of them, but none have made me feel quite the way that Xenonauts does.This is how Xenonauts goes: Pick your starting base, outfit your soldiers with various weapons such as shotguns, RPGs, grenades, riot shields, and sniper rifles based on their stats, send your planes out to intercept UFOs that come within range of your base(s), send out a strike team to recover the downed UFO, use strategy and tactics to successfully eliminate all of the aliens, recover alien artifacts, weapons, etc, get back on the dropship and return home. Have your scientists research new technologies based on the alien artifacts you find, then have your engineers build them using the materials you've recovered in battle. Equip your troops with better weapons and armor so they can deal with increasingly dangerous alien footsoldiers, build faster, more powerful aircrafts to deal with increasingly dangerous alien ships, build tanks to give your troops support in fights, defend your base from attacking UFOs, send out troops to defend cities that are under attack, and send troops in to demolish alien bases. You are trying to keep the various nations around the globe happy. The more you engage and successfully deter alien attacks within their airspace, the more money they will pay you. Ignore a region for a while, and they may give up on the Xenonauts program entirely.The battles will sometimes have you deliberating on a single action for several minutes if there is a lot at stake. You find yourself in a precarious situation. Should you bumrush the alien hope you shotgun it to death before it reacts? Should you stay where you are and lob a grenade, hoping you blow it up? Should you retreat back to safety, allowing the alien to do the same? The AI isn't stupid. Most of the aliens are going to engage you stragically, hiding behind cover, around corners, running when surrounding, throwing grenades when your troops are clumped up. They aren't going to come rushing at you while you hide behind sandbags, allowing themselves to be mowed down. They want YOU to come to them. And they have better technology and sometimes greater numbers. You really have to be patient with this game. You go out there running and gunning at the aliens and I'm certain you will not be successful for very long.The core of the game is the strategic ground battles, of course, but there is strategy at all levels in this game. Money is a big one. You are never going to be able to afford everything you want until maybe the very end of the game. Are you going to build more bases to cover more land? You will certainly need to, but the timing is up to you. Are you going to be able to afford a whole new platoon of troops for that new base? Interceptors? Defense missiles? New bases take up a significant portion of your money. Should you hire more scientists so that you can research new technologies faster? Those scientists cost $10,000 per person per month... and you need to build barracks to house them. Ditto with Engineers, but you'll need more to build more advanced weapons ships and armor. Recently had a battle that went really poorly? You're going to have to hire new soldiers, and help them succeed in battle to gain experience/stats. You have to be smart with your money in this game. Strategic.New technologies take time to research, and more time to build. You need to prioritize. Should you research better weapons or armor first? Is it worth the time researching and building that tank? Should you build that new interceptor now? Do you really need it NOW or can you use the time/money on something else? Should you prioritize new warplanes so that you can protect the nations that fund you? Or should you focus on weapons and armor so that you can raise the survival rate of your troops, making them more experienced and efficient over time? Should you focus on tanks that will draw fire away from your troops, increasing soldier survivability? Should you outfit one soldier with a riot shield? Two? Three? Four? How many RPGs? How many assault rifles? Does your base really need that many missile batteries, or is it just 'nice'?The answers to all of these questions is: Balance. You will need to do everything, ultimately, but you need to prioritize and plan for the short and long term. You'll need to take calculated risks, whether it's in battle or with money. You'll need to make sacrifices (Sure, you'd love to have that 3rd base up NOW, but can you truly afford it now? Or are you risking losing a whole region's funding?). Unlike the games I've mentioned above, you can't do everything in this game. This is not a game where you fight a battle, win, go to the next town, revive your people, buy all the latest equipment and head to the next battle. You can't revive your troops, and you can't simply buy the new equipment you want, because a) you have to research and build everything from scratch, there are no stores, and b) you don't have the money to buy everything anyway. As I said, the strategy is at all levels in this game, and each level affects the others. Balancing all of this is your key to being successful.So what makes Xenonauts special? Ironmade mode. With it, there is a sense of desperation and panic that you will sometimes experience. You are going to take losses. Your strategies aren't always going to work. Plans are going to go awry. You're going to make mistakes. You're going to shake your head, kick yourself, and have regrets. If you're playing on ironman mode, as I HIGHLY recommend, you don't get to reload your last save and save that soldier. He's dead. Forever. That tank that got blown up is gone forever. If you fail an alien terror mission, that city gets wiped from the face of the Earth and you lose significant funding. But maybe you had to retreat from that mission because you were getting your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you? Maybe things didn't go so well, and you decided that the loss in funding was better than losing all of your experienced soldiers and the expensive equipment they were carrying. Sometimes the game feels 'cheap'. Sometimes you will get sniped by an alien you can't even see. One hit KO'd behind cover, soldier gone forever. You didn't even make a mistake. It's a situation you'd have to be clairvoyant to prevent. The aliens are more advanced than you, afterall. They're going to have better weapons and armor. But Xenonauts's shining moments come when you overcome those failures, setbacks, and mistakes. When all the chips are on the table and you're outgunned and outnumbered and you still emerge victorious, although not nearly unscathed. When you are attacking an alien base and half your squad gets wiped out by a grenade thrown from around the corner but you still somehow win. When you're down to your last clip of ammo and half the map is blown up in an alien terror mission and your last two soldiers barely kill the last alien. THAT is what makes this game great.This game makes me feel a way that no other strategy game ever has. And it is EXTREMELY rewarding.

Posted: February 1, 2016
												Xenonauts is an echo from a time when XCOM was X-Com. What makes the game good is not that it hails from X-Com, but rather adds a new life to the game, further expanding on what makes X-Com good. For one, the game's updated graphics allows for the concept of cover to now be a thing, rather than hoping that this wall is going to save me. Secondly, the game adds in different weapons to help breach those pesky UFO doors and not get mowed down in the process. Third, the game does not shaft newer players in the first month, rather, it shafts players in a long, drawn-out, painful fashion. If you want to play X-Com, but don't feel like running DOSbox to play it, or want to see what it'd look like with a updated graphical engine, this game is for you.

Posted: February 13, 2016
												Review:An almost perfect game, especially if your looking for a game like the classic XCOM.  Unfortunatly there are not really any others these days so this game definitely fills the void.  Yeah it has some problems and a few glitches here and there such as an alien, rarely, being able to get that shot off through a wall killing a guy but with the same line of sight back you cant shoot them.  It is rare but it does happen.  The main difference between this game and the classic XCOM is that Xenonauts uses a 2D system rather than the 3D one XCOM: Ufo Defense had.  This has its limitations and is probably the biggest gripe I have with this game because it makes the line of sight issues, among other things.  It calculates the chance of hit, does the math, and then either hits or misses the target while cover dramatically reduces that chance.  This is opposed to XCOM's 3D engine where it instead used a complex calculation with the accuracy taken into account and calculated a trajectory of the bullet and whatever it hit it hit, whether it be a guy way off the side of the target, hitting the guy behind the target, or just flying off the map.  It was much more fun that way, with this game their system is ok but definitely a step back.  On the bright side I hear Goldhawk is using a 3D engine for their sequel so hopefully the next game is going to be the true successor to this genre.Pros:+Great Graphics (for the style they are going for)+Air battles are intense+Streamlined management (you still have to manufacture all the weapons besides the base ones, armour, planes, ect. except the ammo)  +Loadouts. You still have to account for how much ammo you bring, grenades, and everything of that nature with penalties if you bring too much.+Soldiers are now much easier to track (very powerful feature, something XCOM lacked in and you'll understand why when you play it)+Tons of tech+Cover mechanics are great but again I just wish it was a 3D engine+Has room for alot of strategy and different methods of play+Great community and many mods to change your experienceCons:-2D engine which accounts for most of the issues people have with line of sight and accuracy.  It isn't bad but the 3D engine would have been 100x better.  This is my biggest gripe with the game and is mainly the reason I feel the game isn't perfect (otherwise it would have been!)-Most other negative issues relate to the 2D issue such as not being able to through granades over walls, shoot someone in the air if their is a wall in the way, and other annoying little things like that.-Usually each map will have only 1 race of alien, sometimes 2 if they are similar, such as both being robotic for instance.  Theres a mod that changes that but thought it was worth mentioning.Last Thoughts:Personally I did not mind that my dudes would usually get 1-2 shotted as it adds to the difficulty, and for me the realism.  I can't immagine someone would take a few shots from a plasma gun, especially at close range, and keep chugging through like nothing happened.  It is manageable though, and if played right usually the casaulties can stay pretty low.  Also the game is pretty brutal and challenging, you always feel behind.  This game is all about trade offs.  Overall a great foundation for the sequel, but still alot of fun.  Great job Goldhawk amigos!If it had a 3D engine would be 9.5, but alas8.5/10

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Holy crap, this game, smells and looks like the original X-com, but it looks like the original X-com we remember playing with our rose tinted glasses of the past, in laymans terms, that means that the original game didn't look as good as this, but  we'd like to think it did. Couple this with mod support and the outstanding community edition that is available through steam, and this game is a winner winner, chicken dinner. You can play through this game however you want to, do you brink a vehicle or two extra xeonauts? do you bring heavy or light guns? just grenades? pretty much any strategy works on the battlefield if your patient enough to make it work. most games these days hold your hand, this one will help you at the start but just like a parent teaching their child to ride a bike you'll soon notice those hands on your back are gone, how long have they been gone? you don't know because this game is easy to learn, but very hard to master.There will be times when this game will make you want to rage quit, thats normal, thats called building a connection with your troops and then some alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with his plasma power sniper rifle gets a lucky shot and blow out their head/chest cavity with a bolt of plasma, thats what happens when your going up against superior tech. Your only way to win is to get tactical.Although iron man mode isn't the only way to play this game, its singleplayer you play however you want to play, want to load a save game everytime something goes wrong? you can do, its called learning. my first playthrough was somewhat like that, i took my fair share of losses, and even with repeated reloading, the game was still very challenging. My second playthrough is shaping up to be a much tougher, and rougher challenge without the reloading. And if i can justify giving this game another run through you can justify playing it if you have any love of tactical games. ( especially if it is on sale like it is right now!)

Posted: December 21, 2014
												This game is not fair.Let's get that out of the way right off the bat. If you're looking for something you can play well and have no chance of failing horribly, this is not it. One bad mission, one stroke of bad luck, can send you spinning down the path to destruction.However, there are a great many selling points that keep me coming back to this game; while it isn't fair, if you accept that you will have a good time. This game forces you to think. There will be many times when you will think, "oh, there's probably no aliens there; I can afford to rush or leave it unguarded". Well, if you think that, stop yourself. Mistakes are not dealt with lightly in this game, and rushing is not a luxury you can often take.  Likewise, always have a contingency plan for when you miss. No - scratch that- have three. Because if you leave your team in the hands of someone with a shotgun, and that Andron manages to survive those shots, you just lost a valuable team member, if not two. Leave enough time for your rifleman to pop around the corner and finish him off, or else you will cry. Remember - 70% chance to hit is just an optimistic way to say 30% chance to miss. This game does not like impatience.But it's just so *satisfying*! Blowing your first corvette out of the sky, capturing that first xeno, and clearing out every last alien crash site feels great. And you get the satisfaction of knowing you did it right. Plus this game has all of the options you can possibly want in terms of ground battles. It all works just as you'd expect, and the customization in loadouts along with the options you have in ground battles in terms of strategy makes the game very compelling, and keeps me coming back every time I get frustrated. In the end, no, it's not fair, but there's always something you can do to even the odds, and it all depends on just how much time you're willing to take.

Posted: January 14, 2016
												I was pretty late to the X-COM scene, not discovering it until around 2006 or 2007 when a friend insisted I play it. It was not too long before the very unforgiving game won me over. I fell in love with the immense freedom it gave the player on the battlefield. Often rewarding inventive methods of defeating enemies, be it through altering the landscape around you or  experimenting with different load-outs and teams. The ability to build, manage, and defend bases all while balancing available resources was intriguing and rewarding. And naturally the ability to rename soldiers/sacrifices added immense entertainment value as well. Needless to say, I was suitably impressed!With the arrival of the Firaxis version, “Enemy Unknown”, I was skeptical. I learned they had removed many of the mechanics and features I had enjoyed so much in the original. After reading glowing reviews, I finally bit the bullet and picked up while on sale. And I was not disappointed! I still lamented the loss of the of the freedom I enjoyed in the original. However, I found that Firaxis had (in my opinion) made it a far more approachable and user friendly game than the original had been. With flashy graphics and enjoyable combat, it was a pleasurable experience. But all the same, I still missed many of the features from the original which had captured my imagination.Xenonauts came as a bit of a surprise to me though. At first glance it appeared to be no more than a clone of the original X-COM with updated graphics (which initially I was not very impressed by).  And for quite some time I ignored its development. Incidentally it was the same friend who introduced me to the franchise that suggested I try out Xenonauts. After well of 80 hours I can safely say it was a great experience and truly worth successor.The story is very well done. It is surprisingly compelling, and during my first play through I found the progression through the story to be quite exciting as a result. The base building, defense, and geoscape are a fine return to the series roots. You can once again build as many bases as you wish, and optimize them in whatever ways you see fit. The tech tree is also really impressive, beginning with cold war technology, you advance quite steadily into far more lethal technologies. The aliens themselves are well designed and enjoyable (for the most part) to fight. Even the art style which I initially disliked had grown on me. The aesthetic of the aliens, weapons, ships, backgrounds, technology/lore updates are all exceptional and help keep the player engaged.To top everything off, there is a healthy modding community. Often times if you have an issue with the core game, there is a mod out there somewhere which addresses it.Xenonauts is outstanding, and I highly recommend checking it out!

Posted: December 28, 2015
												If you liked the original X-Com and/or Terror From the Deep, you'll probably like this. Xenonauts is a more logical evolution of the gameplay of the older X-Com games than the new 2015 X-Com is. It uses time-units, you can pick up stuff from the ground or put it down, take weapons off dead enemies, etc. There is actual gameplay on the geoscape, multiple bases, etc.It adds a interceptor minigame that's decent, and for the most part removes annoying psionics. Sadly part of that is that there's none for you.Overall, I had a lot of fun with it.

Posted: July 7, 2016
												To give you an idea of what this game is like, I wrote this:You are the last man in your squad, Reapers have zombified every human in the city and to your dismay one of them pursuing you. You are too busy looking behind you to realize you have been backed into an alley,  you look behind you once again to see your adversary facing you, Snappinng It's massive mouth with hundreds of incredibly sharp teeth. You can feel its hot breath against your skin, you think it is the end, and put your rifle's muzzle against your neck. But your luck changes, and you realize the reaper has exhausted their time unit supply. You lower the gun and point it at the reaper, "95% it will hit." you think to yourself. You point your rifle at the reaper's head, and close your eyes. "A 95% chance I will live." You smile and pull the trigger. You hear the gun fire and feel the recoil of the bullet leaving the chamber, you open your eyes and hope to see a headless reaper corpse in front of you. Unfortunate as it is, you missed the shot and the reaper in front of you still has a head and still wants to kill you and use your body as a vessel for its parasitic spawn.10/10 would lose "Pvt. John Mctiggles" exactly like that again.

Posted: January 21, 2016
												The alternative to XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within, or vice versa. Xenonauts sticks closer to the original XCOM than the official reboot, which leads to some notable differences (amongst others). In all three games, you lead a section of infantry against an alien force that's superior both in quality and quantity. Unlike XCOM, though, your troops are actually a crack team of veterans recruited from around the world. That is, your privates can actually hit a target 10 metres away and not freak out when it looks at them funny afterwards. Also in keeping with the traditional game, the clock's been rolled back - but even further than the original, to the late 1970s. Yes, that's right: your soldiers are using M16s and M60s, and the Soviet Union still exists. Your equipment can be far better or far worse than in the "official" reboot as a result.In conclusion, the game is a very good compromise, nestled between XCOM:EU and XCOM:EW with the Long War mod installed. If you want an "easy" game with modern graphics and a minimal air war component, play XCOM:EW. For a surreal-bordering-on-pure-evil level of difficulty, go with Long War. For something that's in the happy medium between the two (or if you just want a nostalgia trip), pick up Xenonauts. Heck, pick up both successors if you want. One can be just as good as the other, depending on what you're looking for.

Posted: January 1, 2016
												Essentially, this is an alternate universe version of XCOM harkening back to the classic titles and done fully in 2D. And how good is that 2d? I love it. Huge respect to the team at Goldhawk for going all in and not taking the easy way out with halfassed 2.5D/3D. In my opinion being 2D really adds to the classic vibe.Compared to Firaxis' XCOM this definitely feels like an older game. It's more complex, much more challenging outside of ground combat. In XCOM you basically only need to worry about ground combat. In Xenonauts you have to maintain multiple bases, multiple teams of soldiers, cast a wide enough net of radars to protect as much of the earth as you can, and manage your air force against the waves of UFOs that even threaten to attack your bases if left unharassed (and if they do they aliens will come in and try to break all your stuff). And all that before you even get to the ground combat. Both games feature similar research that provides gear that you need to stay on even keel with the aliens who get progressively more powerful, and the research also drives the story along in both. Though Xenonauts doesn't really have a story in the way the XCOM does, in Xenonauts the narrative is your own, there's no cutscenes or dialogue or anything.The ground combat is also much more complex in Xenonauts, choosing to use "time units" rather than XCOM's two actions per soldier method. Most weapons have several firing modes available taking different amounts of time units, switching weapons (or grenades) takes time units, etc. Also cover much always always always be used, a soldier left in the middle of the street is liable to get shot by an alien you can't see.One major gripe I have with Xenonauts' ground combat is that downed UFOs only have one way in, the front door. This means you have to funnel your troops in through the front door where a bunch of well armed aliens are sitting waiting violate you. The combat requires well thought out tactics in order to survive, and yet you're forced to charge headlong at angry aliens, ehhhh.On the whole, Xenonauts is a more calculating, complex, slower paced game. XCOM is snappier and more gamey. They both offer a different approach to the alien invasion. Xenonauts is a more niche take to XCOM's mainstream accessibility. Personally, while I recommend this game to XCOM fans or fans of tactical strategy type games, I don't know how much more I can withstand, it's very stressful. It's always heartbreaking to lose your elite guys in XCOM, but in Xenonauts I just keep losing everything, game's hard man!

Posted: February 13, 2016
												Review:An almost perfect game, especially if your looking for a game like the classic XCOM.  Unfortunatly there are not really any others these days so this game definitely fills the void.  Yeah it has some problems and a few glitches here and there such as an alien, rarely, being able to get that shot off through a wall killing a guy but with the same line of sight back you cant shoot them.  It is rare but it does happen.  The main difference between this game and the classic XCOM is that Xenonauts uses a 2D system rather than the 3D one XCOM: Ufo Defense had.  This has its limitations and is probably the biggest gripe I have with this game because it makes the line of sight issues, among other things.  It calculates the chance of hit, does the math, and then either hits or misses the target while cover dramatically reduces that chance.  This is opposed to XCOM's 3D engine where it instead used a complex calculation with the accuracy taken into account and calculated a trajectory of the bullet and whatever it hit it hit, whether it be a guy way off the side of the target, hitting the guy behind the target, or just flying off the map.  It was much more fun that way, with this game their system is ok but definitely a step back.  On the bright side I hear Goldhawk is using a 3D engine for their sequel so hopefully the next game is going to be the true successor to this genre.Pros:+Great Graphics (for the style they are going for)+Air battles are intense+Streamlined management (you still have to manufacture all the weapons besides the base ones, armour, planes, ect. except the ammo)  +Loadouts. You still have to account for how much ammo you bring, grenades, and everything of that nature with penalties if you bring too much.+Soldiers are now much easier to track (very powerful feature, something XCOM lacked in and you'll understand why when you play it)+Tons of tech+Cover mechanics are great but again I just wish it was a 3D engine+Has room for alot of strategy and different methods of play+Great community and many mods to change your experienceCons:-2D engine which accounts for most of the issues people have with line of sight and accuracy.  It isn't bad but the 3D engine would have been 100x better.  This is my biggest gripe with the game and is mainly the reason I feel the game isn't perfect (otherwise it would have been!)-Most other negative issues relate to the 2D issue such as not being able to through granades over walls, shoot someone in the air if their is a wall in the way, and other annoying little things like that.-Usually each map will have only 1 race of alien, sometimes 2 if they are similar, such as both being robotic for instance.  Theres a mod that changes that but thought it was worth mentioning.Last Thoughts:Personally I did not mind that my dudes would usually get 1-2 shotted as it adds to the difficulty, and for me the realism.  I can't immagine someone would take a few shots from a plasma gun, especially at close range, and keep chugging through like nothing happened.  It is manageable though, and if played right usually the casaulties can stay pretty low.  Also the game is pretty brutal and challenging, you always feel behind.  This game is all about trade offs.  Overall a great foundation for the sequel, but still alot of fun.  Great job Goldhawk amigos!If it had a 3D engine would be 9.5, but alas8.5/10

Posted: November 23, 2016
												I have never played any of the previous XCOM games. I just want people who also haven't to know that about me up front.My experience with Xenonauts has been excellent. This is an addictive game that will have you hooked with that 'JUST ONE MORE TURN' addiction that all good games have. I highly recommend this game to any turn-based strategy fan. Before I go any further, if you decide to play this game, you NEED to play it on Ironman mode; that's what makes this game so great. It's a mode where you aren't allowed to save-scum, so all of your actions, and mistakes, are permanent.I consider myself fairly well versed on turn-based strategy games. I'm a 31 year old gamer who has very fond childhood memories of early strategy games like Shining Force, Dark Wizard, Final Fantasy Tactics, OgreBattle, Civilization, Heros of M&M, as well as more modern strategy games like Disgaea. I enjoyed and still enjoy every single one of them, but none have made me feel quite the way that Xenonauts does.This is how Xenonauts goes: Pick your starting base, outfit your soldiers with various weapons such as shotguns, RPGs, grenades, riot shields, and sniper rifles based on their stats, send your planes out to intercept UFOs that come within range of your base(s), send out a strike team to recover the downed UFO, use strategy and tactics to successfully eliminate all of the aliens, recover alien artifacts, weapons, etc, get back on the dropship and return home. Have your scientists research new technologies based on the alien artifacts you find, then have your engineers build them using the materials you've recovered in battle. Equip your troops with better weapons and armor so they can deal with increasingly dangerous alien footsoldiers, build faster, more powerful aircrafts to deal with increasingly dangerous alien ships, build tanks to give your troops support in fights, defend your base from attacking UFOs, send out troops to defend cities that are under attack, and send troops in to demolish alien bases. You are trying to keep the various nations around the globe happy. The more you engage and successfully deter alien attacks within their airspace, the more money they will pay you. Ignore a region for a while, and they may give up on the Xenonauts program entirely.The battles will sometimes have you deliberating on a single action for several minutes if there is a lot at stake. You find yourself in a precarious situation. Should you bumrush the alien hope you shotgun it to death before it reacts? Should you stay where you are and lob a grenade, hoping you blow it up? Should you retreat back to safety, allowing the alien to do the same? The AI isn't stupid. Most of the aliens are going to engage you stragically, hiding behind cover, around corners, running when surrounding, throwing grenades when your troops are clumped up. They aren't going to come rushing at you while you hide behind sandbags, allowing themselves to be mowed down. They want YOU to come to them. And they have better technology and sometimes greater numbers. You really have to be patient with this game. You go out there running and gunning at the aliens and I'm certain you will not be successful for very long.The core of the game is the strategic ground battles, of course, but there is strategy at all levels in this game. Money is a big one. You are never going to be able to afford everything you want until maybe the very end of the game. Are you going to build more bases to cover more land? You will certainly need to, but the timing is up to you. Are you going to be able to afford a whole new platoon of troops for that new base? Interceptors? Defense missiles? New bases take up a significant portion of your money. Should you hire more scientists so that you can research new technologies faster? Those scientists cost $10,000 per person per month... and you need to build barracks to house them. Ditto with Engineers, but you'll need more to build more advanced weapons ships and armor. Recently had a battle that went really poorly? You're going to have to hire new soldiers, and help them succeed in battle to gain experience/stats. You have to be smart with your money in this game. Strategic.New technologies take time to research, and more time to build. You need to prioritize. Should you research better weapons or armor first? Is it worth the time researching and building that tank? Should you build that new interceptor now? Do you really need it NOW or can you use the time/money on something else? Should you prioritize new warplanes so that you can protect the nations that fund you? Or should you focus on weapons and armor so that you can raise the survival rate of your troops, making them more experienced and efficient over time? Should you focus on tanks that will draw fire away from your troops, increasing soldier survivability? Should you outfit one soldier with a riot shield? Two? Three? Four? How many RPGs? How many assault rifles? Does your base really need that many missile batteries, or is it just 'nice'?The answers to all of these questions is: Balance. You will need to do everything, ultimately, but you need to prioritize and plan for the short and long term. You'll need to take calculated risks, whether it's in battle or with money. You'll need to make sacrifices (Sure, you'd love to have that 3rd base up NOW, but can you truly afford it now? Or are you risking losing a whole region's funding?). Unlike the games I've mentioned above, you can't do everything in this game. This is not a game where you fight a battle, win, go to the next town, revive your people, buy all the latest equipment and head to the next battle. You can't revive your troops, and you can't simply buy the new equipment you want, because a) you have to research and build everything from scratch, there are no stores, and b) you don't have the money to buy everything anyway. As I said, the strategy is at all levels in this game, and each level affects the others. Balancing all of this is your key to being successful.So what makes Xenonauts special? Ironmade mode. With it, there is a sense of desperation and panic that you will sometimes experience. You are going to take losses. Your strategies aren't always going to work. Plans are going to go awry. You're going to make mistakes. You're going to shake your head, kick yourself, and have regrets. If you're playing on ironman mode, as I HIGHLY recommend, you don't get to reload your last save and save that soldier. He's dead. Forever. That tank that got blown up is gone forever. If you fail an alien terror mission, that city gets wiped from the face of the Earth and you lose significant funding. But maybe you had to retreat from that mission because you were getting your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you? Maybe things didn't go so well, and you decided that the loss in funding was better than losing all of your experienced soldiers and the expensive equipment they were carrying. Sometimes the game feels 'cheap'. Sometimes you will get sniped by an alien you can't even see. One hit KO'd behind cover, soldier gone forever. You didn't even make a mistake. It's a situation you'd have to be clairvoyant to prevent. The aliens are more advanced than you, afterall. They're going to have better weapons and armor. But Xenonauts's shining moments come when you overcome those failures, setbacks, and mistakes. When all the chips are on the table and you're outgunned and outnumbered and you still emerge victorious, although not nearly unscathed. When you are attacking an alien base and half your squad gets wiped out by a grenade thrown from around the corner but you still somehow win. When you're down to your last clip of ammo and half the map is blown up in an alien terror mission and your last two soldiers barely kill the last alien. THAT is what makes this game great.This game makes me feel a way that no other strategy game ever has. And it is EXTREMELY rewarding.

Posted: June 9, 2015
												Rather than write a long and somewhat scattershot review of the game I'll just say that it's excellent. It's tense and challenging. You'll see soldiers distinguish themselves in combat in terrible situations, and you'll see your vets get killed when things go sideways. You'll have to juggle the competing priorities of the air war and the ground war (hint: focus on the air war) since you can only build so much expensive stuff at once. The only glitches/bugs that really bothered me got patched (timing of bleed damage, Harridan snipers glitching into walls, berserking) and there really wasn't anything else that I feel has gone unresolved. Great game, just know that it's much more complicated than the Firaxis XCOM and will take you a lot longer to finish.

Posted: August 19, 2015
												THE GOOD:  This one is absolutely the spiritual successor to the original X-COM title from the mid-90s.  The avoid a bunch of the RPG gimmicks from the new X-COM games, and leave you with what is much more of a squad-based, turn-based strategy war game.  The atmosphere of the game is very well done, the various game mechanics and combat mechanics are very well balanced (e.g., finding the right balance in base-building between research/industry and defensive coverage of the map, finding the right balance in reserach between ground-based weapons and beefing up your interceptors, etc.).  And the nail-biting tension around losing your squad in battles was exactly the same!It  took me right back to the days of playing the original X-COM, and that is high praise indeed!There is also a small but very enthusiastic modding community for this game, so check out the Steam Workshop.THE BAD:  I found it a little bit of a grind later on in the game.  Too many repetitive base assaults, too many repetitive missions to "kill and autopsy" or "capture and interrogate" one more unfamiliar alien, and the formula of "capture this type of alien" to advance the main story line got a bit stale after a while.  That was after 60+ hours of delightful game play, so take that with a grain of salt.

Posted: December 26, 2016
The goodXenonauts atcheaves what it set out to do: To be a spiritual succsessor to the first Xcom game.It has improved in some aspects over the original Xcom: The aircraft combat is less random and more skill based with its up to 3 v 3 air battles where you actually get to controll          the positioning and weapon useage of your aircraft. As opposed to the original where it was mostly luck based wheter your interceptors hit and/or/did not get hit in an encounter.The art in the xenopedia/ufopedia is what I personally enjoied alot in both the original and Xenonauts.  Combat shields are a great addition to the game.The modding scene is still active and people are givig their best to make the game better.The badFlatland! The geoscape is flat and radar ranges and distances make no geological sense because there is no consideration for map deformation. If you like globes you will not find any here.The ground combat sprites look plane, like they made some models in a 3d art program and animated them there. Then made a bunch of low resolution images of the models to make the art for the ground combat. The art there has no character at all unlike the original Xcom. Unlike the original Xcom you can not make your soldiers or aleans: Jump down from roofs. Throw anything besides granades and explosives. Wake up from being uncouncious. Get tired from running. Take kontroll of the minds of aleans or civilians. Get hit in specific body parts and and lose apropreat stats for being wounded.Difficult to make mods for: The game engine is at best a derelict wreck with no source. It reports no errors and just crashes when things go wrong. Wich makes finding bugs in your mods way more difficult than it has to be. Due  to the difficulitys in the games development the game is in numerous separate peaces of code that use different files for tha same things. For example the weapon stats in the xenopedia/ufopedia and inventory and ground combat calculations are all in different files. While making a new weapon for the game you have to mod all three of the files witch all have slightly different formats.ConclusionsA polished game it certainly is not. But for the price they are asking it has sertainly given me many houers of entertainmant. And many of its smaller flaws, exept the ones I mentioned, have been fixed by the modders. So if you are looking for something a bit more like the old Xcom yo might want to give this game a try. But if you are short on money you might want to save up for the seqel.

Posted: February 28
												I'm playing the community edition, which polishes up some of the mechanics.  This game is pretty solid, and well thought out.  The geoscape and air combat feel pretty authentic, and that alone sets this apart from the new XCOM.  The ground combat is tedious, but in a good way.  I'm constantly counting my TUs trying to decide when to run up to an alien to blast their face off with a shotgun, and when I pull it off, it is extremely satisfying.The CE maps are challenging even in the early game, and this game doesn't ease you into the mechanics as much as XCOM did.  I play this game on normal difficulty, and I'm not ashamed to save scum because sometimes I still take dead soldiers at the end of a mission if the trade off was worth it.  That's because the risks and rewards in this game are balanced, and the progression is logical.  I'd reccomend this game if you like spending an hour planning every 5 minutes of action.

Posted: April 14
												This is a good alternate Xcom game.  The community based mod is excellent, and really enhances the game as well.  I played this game for hours in vanilla.  Then I played it again for hours with the mod.  If you are a diehard Xcom: UFO defense fan, then this game is just for you.  It isn't as pretty as XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but it has more research content than Enemy Unknown.  If you get the community addons, well, you just found your favorite XCOM game.  I prefer less flashy too, so older computers can easily run this.
